Leadership&quot;,&quot;buttonPageId&quot;:null,&quot;buttonText&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;_page&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;160046619836293016&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;About NCSSM&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;blocks&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/about&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:11,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;about ncssm&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;about ncssm about&quot;,&quot;highSearchWords&quot;:[&quot;about&quot;,&quot;ncssm&quot;],&quot;lowSearchText&quot;:&quot;about ncssm about heighthistogramfunnylarge our history the school s three founders former north carolina governor james b hunt jr former north carolina governor senator and duke university president terry sanford and academician and author john ehle envisioned an institution that would invest in the state s human and intellectual capital to build leadership and economic progress in 1980 during governor hunt s first administration north carolina school of science and mathematics opened on the grounds of the former watts hospital in durham with 150 high school juniors it was the first school of its kind a public residential high school welcoming students from across the state to study a specialized curriculum emphasizing science and mathematics but also offering humanities courses athletics and extracurricular opportunities the founders early vision has matured into a vital institution that models and advocates for excellence in public education in 2007 the school became the 17th constituent of the university of north carolina system ncssm alumni alumni alumni opening opportunities for students from every corner of our state each year we enroll talented students from all 13 congressional districts and nearly each of north carolina s 100 counties evolving into an online resource and partner to teachers school districts we began as a residential school but we ve grown to be so much more during the 2014 2015 academic year for the first time more students were enrolled in ncssm online 720 than in our residential program 680 we also offer courses professional development and other resources for teachers and school districts across the state nationally recognized internationally admired for nearly 15 years newsweek has ranked ncssm as a top public high school in the country the washington post also categorizes ncssm as one of the top performing high schools nationwide a number of schools globally have modeled themselves after our school proving north carolina students can compete and win globally within the last 5 years ncssm students have won or placed in the singapore international mathematics challenge conrad spirit of innovation award moody s mathematics challenge and scores of other contests a good sign for our state s economy and future cultivating community offering real world learning experiences we require all students to complete 60 hours of service with a north carolina nonprofit before their senior year we also encourage internships mentorships and other opportunities to be engaged in real world learning experiences a young school evolves timeline of key dates 1978 the north carolina general assembly establishes the north carolina school of science and mathematics to provide challenging educational opportunities for students with special interests and potential in the sciences and mathematics 1980 first class of 150 juniors enters the school on the grounds of the former watts hospital in durham 1988 together with peers at a handful of similar schools nc school of science and math leaders helps found the national consortium of specialized secondary schools of math science and technology now the national consortium of secondary stem schools 1994 ncssm offers its first distance education classes broadcasting on public television channels 2007 ncssm becomes the 17th constituent institution of the university of north carolina system 2008 first cohort the class of 2010 enters ncssm online earning certificates of completion by supplementing their education at local high schools with virtual courses 2011 ncssm sets the guinness world record for largest food drive in single location in 24 hours collecting 559 885 pounds of food to benefit the food bank of central eastern north carolina which serves 34 counties in our state kalila 8 200 alumni our alumni are making an impact in wide ranging fields as leaders in the sciences technology education business the arts and more across north carolina and beyond meet a few of them here learn about some of them here innovation it s in our school s dna our school s three founders former north carolina governor james b hunt jr former north carolina governor senator and duke university president terry sanford and academician and author john ehle envisioned an institution that would invest in the state s human and intellectual capital to build leadership and economic progress in 1980 during governor hunt s first administration north carolina school of science and mathematics opened on the grounds of the former watts hospital in durham with 150 high school juniors it was the first school of its kind a public residential high school welcoming students from across the state to study a specialized curriculum emphasizing science and mathematics but also offering humanities courses athletics and extracurricular opportunities the founders early vision has matured into a vital institution that models and advocates for excellence in public education eighteen similar schools have sprung from our model in the u s and overseas roberts and board leadership leadership meet chancellor todd roberts our board of trustees and ncssm foundation board of directors other elected boards and senior administrators all helping to guide our school and ensure that it fulfills its mission of advancing learning across north carolina meet our leaders nc counties map impact across nc and beyond ncssm educates students from all 13 nc congressional districts and nearly all 100 nc counties in its programs residential online and videoconferencing increasingly our faculty and staff are sharing their expertise in stem education and learning innovations for talented students and our 8 200 plus alumni serve as leaders in the sciences technology education business the arts and more across north carolina and beyond see ncssm s reach meet some of our alumni leadership engaged leaders meet chancellor todd roberts our board of trustees and ncssm foundation board of directors other elected boards and senior administrators all helping to guide our school and ensure that it fulfills its mission of advancing learning across north carolina impact across north videoconferencing our 8 200 plus alumni serve as leaders in the sciences technology education business the arts and more across north carolina and beyond contact us got questions find contact communications staff and other official school information here our mission advancing public education the mission of north carolina school of science and mathematics is to educate academically talented students to become state national and global leaders in science technology engineering and mathematics advance public education in north carolina and inspire innovation for the betterment of humankind through challenging residential online summer and virtual learning driven by instructional excellence and the excitement of discovery fueling innovation on and off campus north carolina school of science and mathematics models how a statewide approach to collaboration and the use of physical and virtual spaces can create tremendous innovation in public education in 2015 ncssm won the spaces for innovation challenge sponsored by the north carolina state university s institute for emerging issues with the video right helping to tell our story of innovation&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\n\\n \\nOur History\\n\\n\\nThe school's three founders — former North Carolina Governor James B. Hunt Jr.; former North Carolina governor, senator and Duke University president Terry Sanford; and academician and author John Ehle — envisioned an institution that would invest in the state's human and intellectual capital to build leadership and economic progress.\\n\\n\\nIn 1980, during Governor Hunt's first administration, North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics opened on the grounds of the former Watts Hospital in Durham with 150 high school juniors. It was the first school of its kind — a public, residential high school welcoming students from across the state to study a specialized curriculum emphasizing science and mathematics but also offering humanities courses, athletics, and extracurricular opportunities.\\n\\n\\nThe founders' early vision has matured into a vital institution that models and advocates for excellence in public education. In 2007, the school became the 17th constituent of the University of North Carolina system. \\nNCSSM Alumni \\nOpening opportunities for&nbsp;students from every corner of our state\\n\\n\\nEach year we enroll talented students from all 13 congressional districts and nearly each of North Carolina's 100 counties. \\nEvolving into an online resource and partner to teachers, school districts\\n\\n\\nWe began as a residential school, but we've grown to be so much more.&nbsp;During the 2014-2015 academic year, for the first time, more students were enrolled in NCSSM Online (720) than in our residential program (680). We also offer courses, professional development, and other resources for teachers and school districts across the state. \\nNationally recognized, internationally admired\\n\\n\\nFor nearly 15 years, Newsweek has ranked NCSSM as a top public high school in the country. The Washington Post also categorizes NCSSM as one of the top-performing high schools nationwide. A number of schools globally have modeled themselves after our school. \\nProving North Carolina students can compete and win globally\\n\\n\\nWithin the last 5 years, NCSSM students have won or placed in the Singapore International Mathematics Challenge, Conrad Spirit of Innovation Award, Moody’s Mathematics Challenge, and scores of other contests&nbsp;— a good sign for our state's&nbsp;economy and future. \\nCultivating community, offering\\n\\nreal-world learning experiences\\n\\n\\nWe require all students to complete 60 hours of service with a North Carolina nonprofit before their senior year. We also encourage internships, mentorships, and other opportunities to&nbsp;be engaged in real-world learning experiences. \\nA young school evolves:\\n\\ntimeline of&nbsp;key dates\\n\\n\\n1978&nbsp;\\n\\nThe North Carolina General Assembly establishes the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to provide challenging educational opportunities for students with special interests and potential in the sciences and mathematics.\\n\\n\\n1980&nbsp;\\n\\nFirst class of 150 juniors enters the school, on the grounds of the former Watts Hospital in Durham\\n\\n\\n1988&nbsp;\\n\\nTogether with peers at a handful of similar schools, NC School of Science and Math leaders helps found the National Consortium of Specialized Secondary Schools of Math, Science and Technology, now the&nbsp;National Consortium of Secondary STEM Schools\\n\\n\\n1994&nbsp;\\n\\nNCSSM offers its first distance education classes, broadcasting on public television channels\\n\\n\\n2007&nbsp;\\n\\nNCSSM becomes the 17th constituent institution of the University of North Carolina system\\n\\n\\n2008&nbsp;\\n\\nFirst cohort, the Class of 2010, enters NCSSM Online, earning certificates of completion by supplementing their education at local high schools with&nbsp;virtual courses\\n\\n\\n2011\\n\\nNCSSM sets the Guinness world record for largest food drive in single location in 24 hours, collecting 559,885 pounds of food to benefit the Food Bank of Central &amp; Eastern North Carolina, which serves 34 counties in our state.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\n8,200 alumni\\n\\n\\nOur alumni are making an impact in wide-ranging&nbsp;fields — as leaders in the sciences,&nbsp;technology, education, business, the arts and more, across North Carolina and beyond.&nbsp;Meet a few of them here.\\n\\n\\nLearn about some of them here \\nInnovation: It's in our school's DNA.\\n\\n\\nOur school's three founders — former North Carolina Governor James B. Hunt Jr.; former North Carolina governor, senator and Duke University president Terry Sanford; and academician and author John Ehle — envisioned an institution that would invest in the state's human and intellectual capital to build leadership and economic progress.\\n\\n\\nIn 1980, during Governor Hunt's first administration, North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics opened on the grounds of the former Watts Hospital in Durham with 150 high school juniors. It was the first school of its kind — a public, residential high school welcoming students from across the state to study a specialized curriculum emphasizing science and mathematics but also offering humanities courses, athletics, and extracurricular opportunities.\\n\\n\\nThe founders' early vision has matured into a vital institution that models and advocates for excellence in public education. Eighteen similar schools have sprung from our model, in the U.S. and overseas. \\nLeadership\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nLeadership\\n\\n\\nMeet Chancellor Todd Roberts, our Board of Trustees and NCSSM Foundation Board of Directors, other&nbsp;elected boards, and senior administrators, all helping to guide our school and ensure that it fulfills its mission of advancing learning across North Carolina.\\n\\n\\nMeet our leaders \\nImpact Across NC and Beyond\\n\\n\\nNCSSM educates students from all 13 NC congressional districts and nearly all 100 NC counties in its programs: residential, online, and videoconferencing. Increasingly our faculty and staff are sharing their expertise in STEM education and learning innovations for talented students. And our 8,200-plus alumni&nbsp;serve as leaders in the sciences,&nbsp;technology, education, business, the arts and more, across North Carolina and beyond,\\n\\n\\nSee NCSSM's reach,&nbsp;meet some of our alumni \\nLeadership&nbsp; \\nEngaged leaders\\n\\n\\nMeet Chancellor Todd Roberts, our Board of Trustees and NCSSM Foundation Board of Directors, other&nbsp;elected boards, and senior administrators, all helping to guide our school and ensure that it fulfills its mission of advancing learning across North Carolina.&nbsp; \\nImpact Across North Carolina and Beyond \\nExtending our reach\\n\\n\\nNCSSM educates students from all 13 North Carolina congressional districts and nearly all 100 NC counties in its programs: residential, online, and videoconferencing. Our 8,200-plus alumni&nbsp;serve as leaders in the sciences,&nbsp;technology, education, business, the arts and more, across North Carolina and beyond,&nbsp; \\nContact Us \\nGot questions?\\n\\n\\nFind contact information for NCSSM faculty, staff, and administrators, check job openings, download logos, reach our communications staff,&nbsp;and other official school information here.&nbsp; \\n\\n\\nEngaged, inspiring leaders\\n\\n\\nMeet Chancellor Todd Roberts, our Board of Trustees and NCSSM Foundation Board of Directors, other&nbsp;elected boards, and senior administrators, all helping to guide our school and ensure that it fulfills its mission of advancing learning across North Carolina.&nbsp;\\n \\nOur impact, across North Carolina and beyond\\n\\n\\nNCSSM educates students from all 13 North Carolina congressional districts and nearly all 100 NC counties in its programs: residential, online, and videoconferencing. Our 8,200-plus alumni&nbsp;serve as leaders in the sciences,&nbsp;technology, education, business, the arts, and more, across North Carolina and beyond,&nbsp;&nbsp; \\nContact us, emergency info, job postings\\n\\n\\nFind contact information for NCSSM faculty, staff, and administrators, check job openings, download logos, reach our communications staff,&nbsp;and other official school information here.&nbsp; \\nOur mission: Advancing public education&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nThe mission of North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics is to:&nbsp;educate academically talented students&nbsp;to become state, national, and global leaders in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics;&nbsp;advance public education in North Carolina;&nbsp;and&nbsp;inspire innovation&nbsp;for the betterment of humankind, through challenging residential, online, summer, and virtual learning driven by instructional excellence and the excitement of discovery.&nbsp; \\nFueling innovation,&nbsp;\\n\\non and off campus\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics models how a statewide approach to collaboration and the use of physical and virtual spaces can create tremendous innovation in public education.\\n\\n\\nIn 2015, NCSSM won the Spaces for Innovation Challenge sponsored by the North Carolina State University's Institute for Emerging Issues, with the video (right) helping to tell our story of innovation.\\n\\n&nbsp;&quot;,&quot;blockGroups&quot;:{&quot;main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;banner&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;319351351247847342&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;392511138941808401&quot;}]},&quot;main_890995119800019694_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;threeColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;434275700785670856&quot;}]},&quot;main_37808230797110993_col1&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;18553620143166869&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;390515047638749824&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;4844765917426404&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;261059222540249945&quot;}]},&quot;main_392511138941808401_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;373685843740542283&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;43715365391480679&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;161855539513904449&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;69301300852853499&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;201702540745068399&quot;}]}},&quot;main_319351351247847342_banner&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about:main_319351351247847342_banner&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;image&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;itemType&quot;:{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Image(s)&quot;,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;icon-image&quot;,&quot;css&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;},&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w676627665685268861&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;276024083845561230&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;276024083845561230&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlink History</h2>\\n\\n<p>The school's three founders — former North Carolina Governor James B. Hunt Jr.; former North Carolina governor, senator and Duke University president Terry Sanford; and academician and author John Ehle — envisioned an institution that would invest in the state's human and intellectual capital to build leadership and economic progress.</p>\\n\\n<p>In 1980, during Governor Hunt's first administration, North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics opened on the grounds of the former Watts Hospital in Durham with 150 high school juniors. It was the first school of its kind — a public, residential high school welcoming students from across the state to study a specialized curriculum emphasizing science and mathematics but also offering humanities courses, athletics, and extracurricular opportunities.</p>\\n\\n<p>The founders' early vision has matured into a vital institution that models and advocates for excellence in public education. In 2007, the school became the 17th constituent of the University of North Carolina system.</p>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_130812674658080670_sectionHeader&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about:main_130812674658080670_sectionHeader&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h2>NCSSM opportunities for&nbsp;students from every corner of our state</h3>\\n\\n<p>Each year we enroll talented students from all 13 congressional districts and nearly each of North Carolina's 100 counties.</p>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_107715495624316074_body&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about:main_107715495624316074_body&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h3>Evolving into an online resource and partner to teachers, school districts</h3>\\n\\n<p>We began as a residential school, but we've grown to be so much more.&nbsp;During the 2014-2015 academic year, for the first time, more students were enrolled in <strong>NCSSM Online</strong> (720) than in our <strong>residential program</strong> (680). We also offer courses, professional development, and other resources for teachers and school districts across the state.</p>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_796608890638384945_body&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about:main_796608890638384945_body&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h3>Nationally recognized, internationally admired</h3>\\n\\n<p>For nearly 15 years, <em>Newsweek</em> has ranked NCSSM as a<strong> top public high school in the country</strong>. <em>The Washington Post</em> also categorizes NCSSM as one of the top-performing high schools nationwide. A number of schools globally have modeled themselves after our school.</p>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_711509524280512570_body&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about:main_711509524280512570_body&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h3>Proving young school evolves:<br />\\ntimeline of&nbsp;key dates</h3>\\n\\n<p><strong>1978</strong>&nbsp;<br />\\nThe North Carolina General Assembly establishes the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to provide challenging educational opportunities for students with special interests and potential in the sciences and mathematics.</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>1980</strong>&nbsp;<br />\\nFirst class of 150 juniors enters the school, on the grounds of the former Watts Hospital in Durham</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>1988</strong>&nbsp;<br />\\nTogether with peers at a handful of similar schools, NC School of Science and Math leaders helps found the National Consortium of Specialized Secondary Schools of Math, Science and Technology, now the&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://ncsss.org/\\&quot;>National Consortium of Secondary STEM Schools</a></p>\\n\\n<p><strong>1994</strong>&nbsp;<br />\\nNCSSM offers its first distance education classes, broadcasting on public television channels</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>2007</strong>&nbsp;<br />\\nNCSSM becomes the 17th constituent institution of the <a href=\\&quot;http://northcarolina.edu/\\&quot;>University of North Carolina system</a></p>\\n\\n<p><strong>2008</strong>&nbsp;<br />\\nFirst cohort, the Class of 2010, enters NCSSM Online, earning certificates of completion by supplementing their education at local high schools with&nbsp;virtual courses</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>2011</strong><br />\\nNCSSM sets the Guinness world record for largest food drive in single location in 24 hours, collecting 559,885 pounds of food to benefit the Food Bank of Central &amp;amp; Eastern North Carolina, which serves 34 counties in our It's in our school's DNA.</h2>\\n\\n<p>Our school's three founders — former North Carolina Governor James B. Hunt Jr.; former North Carolina governor, senator and Duke University president Terry Sanford; and academician and author John Ehle — envisioned an institution that would invest in the state's human and intellectual capital to build leadership and economic progress.</p>\\n\\n<p>In 1980, during Governor Hunt's first administration, North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics opened on the grounds of the former Watts Hospital in Durham with 150 high school juniors. It was the first school of its kind — a public, residential high school welcoming students from across the state to study a specialized curriculum emphasizing science and mathematics but also offering humanities courses, athletics, and extracurricular opportunities.</p>\\n\\n<p>The founders' early vision has matured into a vital institution that models and advocates for excellence in public education. Eighteen similar schools have sprung from our model, in the U.S. and overseas.</p>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_330127536226030988_image&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/about:main_330127536226030988_image&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;featureImage&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w48070626442973738&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;490313617270937180&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;490313617270937180&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;490313617270937180&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-11T22:18:31.679Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;founders&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;founders&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;b6cba5048083a7f127002f6cc5b7ec0a&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:3755,&quot;height&quot;:2997,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;founders climate change biology to poetry writing and music theory dsc 0073 science the science department offers a broad range of courses from biology and environmental science to chemistry and physics with a focus on hands on learning our science instructors model and encourage the skills of scientific inquiry as well as the curiosity openness to new ideas and skepticism that characterize science robotic future for 35 years our school has been opening doors of opportunity for talented young north carolinians&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;Add whatever you want And it's lookin great!\\n\\n&nbsp;  \\nWhy a residential experience?\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nLearning beyond the classroom\\n\\n\\nNCSSM is an intellectually stimulating, diverse, and collaborative community. We take learning beyond the classroom, with a core curriculum focused on hands-on learning, and real-world experiences like research and mentorship opportunities.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nAward-winning faculty\\n\\n\\nOur award-winning faculty are not only skilled instructors, but are leaders in their fields, with years of experience in mathematics, the sciences, and the humanities. Our instructors are committed to the learning experience of each student, and bring their professional experience to the classroom, broadening the experience for each student.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nA focus on students\\n\\n\\nWe focus on providing students a world-class education that gives them the skills and knowledge they need to design their own future. Students have the flexibility to custom-tailor their coursework to their interests, taking classes in everything from graph theory and climate change biology to&nbsp;poetry writing and music theory.\\n \\nScience\\n\\n\\nThe science department&nbsp;offers a broad range of courses from biology and environmental science to chemistry and physics with a focus&nbsp;on hands-on learning.&nbsp;Our science instructors model and encourage the skills of scientific inquiry as well as the curiosity, openness to new ideas, and skepticism that characterize science.&nbsp; \\nEngineering and Technology\\n\\n\\nCourses in NCSSM's newest department allow students to tackle specialties such as computer science,&nbsp;robotics, and architecture. Our faculty teach students to address complex real-world problems through critical thinking and subject matter expertise.&nbsp;College-level engineering courses offer a head start on the intensive undergraduate engineering programs. \\nMathematics\\n\\n\\nOur mathematics department offers a wide variety of challenging courses. As nationally recognized experts in mathematical modeling and other practices, our faculty encourage students to think deeply about the mathematical concepts they learn and to apply those concepts to real-world situations. \\nHumanities\\n\\n\\nIn our humanities courses, students learn to think critically and creatively, to open themselves to new ideas and new ways of thinking, and to push beyond easy answers to original solutions and responses. They'll&nbsp;also develop their capacity to express ideas in clear, effective speech and writing — not to mention learning to empathize with others. \\nWhy residential?&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nWhy a residential experience?&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nAllan Jiang ’14 \\n\\n\\nHometown: Raleigh\\n\\n\\nCollege: Stanford, studying computer science\\n\\n\\nFavorite memory: Google Mini-Term to see other computer science projects\\n\\n\\nFavorite hangout on campus: SWINGS!\\n\\n\\nHow has NCSSM affected you? \\&quot;It really expanded my horizons, I got exposure to a lot more than I would have at other schools. Science and Math lets people actually explore their strengths and find something they love.”&nbsp; \\nRecent Alumni \\nGary Li '11\\n\\n\\nHometown: Charlotte\\n\\n\\nCollege: Columbia ’15, now associate at a tech startup\\n\\n\\nFavorite activity: NCSSM soccer team\\n\\n\\nProudest moment: Becoming a finalist at the Conrad Spirit of Innovation Challenge\\n\\n\\nHow has NCSSM affected you? “I met some of my best friends at NCSSM and have memories I can cherish for a lifetime.”&nbsp; \\nDanielle Dejournett '14\\n\\n\\nHometown:&nbsp;Asheville\\n\\n\\nCollege:&nbsp;University of Michigan, majoring in biochemistry and Spanish&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nFavorite hangout spot:&nbsp;PFM [aka the cafeteria]\\n\\n\\nProudest moment:&nbsp;being&nbsp;awarded \\&quot;best titration\\&quot; in my chemistry lab by&nbsp;Dr. Bruno\\n\\n\\nHow has NCSSM affected you?&nbsp;\\&quot;NCSSM made me the best version of myself. I was not only challenged academically, but I was also pushed to expand my social network. The students and faculty at NCSSM are unlike any other. They will push you to succeed and will always be there to support you along your journey. The passion I saw in the people at NCSSM is something I strive to reflect in my life.\\&quot; \\nStudent Life&nbsp; \\nAn intellectually stimulating, diverse, and collaborative community\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics focuses on providing students a world-class education, equipping them with the&nbsp;&nbsp;skills and knowledge they need to design their future.&nbsp;NCSSM is an intellectually stimulating, diverse, and collaborative community.&nbsp; \\nExplore our departments\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nMeet Our Students \\nOur science courses&nbsp;focus on the skills of scientific inquiry as well as the&nbsp;curiosity, openness to new ideas, and skepticism that characterize science, with topics from biology and environmental science to chemistry and physics.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nFrom computer science to&nbsp;robotics to&nbsp;architecture, college-level engineering courses offer a head start for university engineering programs.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nDiscover mathematics in a whole new way.&nbsp;As nationally recognized experts in mathematical modeling and other practices, our faculty encourage students to think deeply about the concepts they learn and to apply those concepts to real-world situations.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nNCSSM is more than just science and math. Learn to think critically and creatively, open yourself up to new ideas and ways of thinking, and push beyond easy answers to original solutions and responses in our humanities courses.&nbsp; \\nDesign your future.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nWe take learning beyond the classroom with a core curriculum focused on hands-on learning and real-world experiences.&nbsp;Our award-winning faculty are skilled instructors and leaders in their fields.&nbsp; \\nA chance to grow personally and socially\\n\\n\\nThe residential experience increases the depth and breadth of all students’ education and growth. Our Student Life staff offer opportunities and support as, over the course of two years, students form lifelong friendships and a strong sense of community. \\nMeet some Unicorns\\n\\n\\nOur students hail from all corners of the state, with interests as varied as their backgrounds. Meet some of our&nbsp;current students and hear from recent alumni about what their NCSSM experience so special.&nbsp; \\nFor Families\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nFamilies are members of the Unicorn community, too\\n\\n\\nIt's not always an easy decision to send your high school student to school away from home.&nbsp;Here you'll find answers to many questions you may have,&nbsp;learn how to connect with other families and how you can pitch in, on campus and off. \\nAn intellectually stimulating, diverse, and collaborative community\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics focuses on providing students a world-class education, equipping them with the&nbsp;&nbsp;skills and knowledge they need to design their future.&nbsp;NCSSM is an intellectually stimulating, diverse, and collaborative community.&nbsp;&nbsp;  \\nWelcome to an intellectually challenging, diverse, and collaborative community.\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics focuses on providing students a world-class education. In the classroom and out, we equip &nbsp;students with the&nbsp;skills and knowledge they need to design their future. For 35 years, our school has been opening&nbsp;doors of opportunity for talented young North Carolinians.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;&quot;,&quot;blockGroups&quot;:{&quot;main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;banner&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;223364179886357782&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;863819869327218339&quot;}]},&quot;main_860888287713704736_col1&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;6607001627526940&quot;}]},&quot;main_860888287713704736_col1_6607001627526940_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;threeColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;657150783623536275&quot;}]},&quot;main_863819869327218339_col1&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;152323098831189044&quot;}]},&quot;main_863819869327218339_col1_583031266832612825_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[]},&quot;main_863819869327218339_col1_152323098831189044_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;773328363780383&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;227285223111359770&quot;}]},&quot;main_172850861107900141_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;191417635825828643&quot;}]},&quot;main_410106877848201_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;sectionHeader&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;876171286290039591&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;threeColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;106260743272463937&quot;}]},&quot;main_863819869327218339_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;16029826888354331&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;725303882145296194&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;962249843316731696&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;112546267371183722&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;twoColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;574162740496852051&quot;}]},&quot;main_412015195832404897_main& walkoncampus unlike many colleges and universities ncssm is not an open campus our first priority is the safety of our enrolled student population in addition to our popular admissions open houses we offer individual tours tuesday friday at 10 45 am and 1 pm click here to email us in advance of the day that you would like to visit academics admissions academics admissions academics admissions how to apply eligible applicants may apply to either ncssm s residential or online program or both using one electronic application there is no cost to apply and no tuition for either program in order to complete the 2016 2017 application process and be considered for the ncssm class of 2019 potential applicants must complete all of the requirements within the required time frames step 1 determine if you are eligible applicants must currently be in the 10th grade it is the policy of the north carolina school of science and mathematics to enroll only students who are legal residents of the state of north carolina as defined by g s 116 235 or whose parent or legal guardian is an active duty member of the armed services who is abiding in north carolina incident to active military duty provided the student shares the abode of that parent by december 1 of the school year in which the student applies for admission the 10th grade year and who otherwise meet the admissions criteria of the school step 2 complete an application via cfnc org the next application opens october 15 2016 ncssm has partnered with the college foundation of north carolina cfnc to create the ncssm electronic application to complete an application you must have a cfnc account go to www cfnc org read through the instructions and create a cfnc account once you have created an account or if you already have a cfnc account log into cfnc org click apply and to college next click on application hub now click on start an application use the search tool and type in nc and select north carolina school of science and math from the pull down menu to start the application under intent to apply use the drop downs to indicate which program s you intend to apply to you can save the application and return to it as long as you submit it by the deadline all ncssm applications must be completed via the cfnc org electronic application there are no exceptions applicants must have each section of the application completed by january 15 2017 there are no exceptions to this deadline questions for determining residency are built into the electronic application however some applicants may be required to provide additional documentation and will be contacted by an office of admissions residency expert after their application has been submitted note applicants will use this cfnc account to submit a transcript and monitor their admissions progress and status step 3 take the sat by january 21 2017 all applicants must take the sat as a sophomore as part of the application process applicants do not have to take the sat before creating an application account ncssm does not require the essay portion of the new sat only score reports from tests administered on the following dates will be accepted october 1 2016 november 5 2016 december 3 2016 january 21 2017 for students requiring testing accommodations due to disabilities please visit the following site as test registration and administration dates can vary http www collegeboard org students with disabilities calendar we recommend that applicants register to take the sat prior to the january test date test site cancellations due to inclement weather often occur during january to ensure that test results are sent directly to the ncssm admissions office students using a hard copy of the sat registration form must enter the ncssm special code 2241 in block 11a students registering online for the sat must select north carolina school of science and math from the list of schools to send the score report step 4 obtain teacher counselor evaluations february 1 to march 15 2017 please read the evaluation guidebook for applicants if you have questions about the evaluation process as part of the application process applicants must secure evaluations from three teachers and his or her current guidance counselor applicants must have a teacher evaluation form completed by their 9th or 10th grade science teacher 9th or 10th grade mathematics teacher 9th or 10th grade english teacher it is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their teachers and counselor to complete an evaluation on their behalf and add that information in uniapp february 1 2017 applicant family receive email notification that teacher and counselor evaluation electronic link has been emailed and teachers and counselors are granted access to the electronic form march 15 2017 deadline for receipt of teacher and counselor evaluation forms by ncssm teacher evaluation and counselor report forms will be accessible in our evaluation website step 5 submit a transcript with fall 2016 grades march 1 to march 15 2017 the ncssm office of admissions will accept transcripts from march 1 until march 15 to request a transcript using cfnc org s transcript manager log into cfnc org under the apply section click to college and then transcript manager select north carolina school of science and math from the pull down menu read more about submitting transcripts step 6 attend discovery day residential only must attend on the date assigned by county in addition to the requirements listed above all residential applicants are required to attend an assigned discovery day on the campus of ncssm all applicants must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian on discovery day residential applicants will take an ncssm math test parents will attend an information session highlighting academics and student life details concerning discovery day will be emailed after students have completed and submitted their application discovery day i february 18 2017 discovery day ii february 25 2017 discovery day iii march 4 2017 follow your progress applicants will be able to follow their progress during the admissions process using a secure ncssm web link after the application deadline on january 15 2017 and by january 19th at the latest each applicant will be emailed a link and password to monitor their application process and final status applicants will be able to see whether or not their sats and evaluations have been received and processed by ncssm admissions&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nStats and scores\\n\\n\\nDownload the 2015-2016 residential profile for information on SAT scores, college acceptances, and more. \\nIn his own words\\n\\n\\nClick to read why Braxton Baird '15, says \\&quot;Attending NCSSM before college was the best decision of my life.\\&quot; \\nPeer&nbsp;to Peer\\n\\n\\nStudents answer frequently asked questions about attending North Carolina School of Science and Math.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nClick here&nbsp;to browse the video interviews. \\nFrom September to December, our admissions counselors present information sessions across the state.&nbsp;Click here to see the schedule of recruitment events by county. \\nUnlike many colleges and universities, NCSSM is&nbsp;not an open campus. Our first priority is the safety of our enrolled student population.\\n\\n\\nIn addition to our popular admissions open houses, we offer individual tours Tuesday—Friday at 10:45 am and 1 pm. Click here to email&nbsp;us&nbsp;in advance of the day that you would like to visit. \\nAcademics Admissions  \\nAcademics Admissions\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nAcademics Admissions\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nHow to Apply\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nEligible applicants may apply to either NCSSM's residential or online program, or both,&nbsp;using one electronic application.&nbsp;There is no cost to apply and no tuition for either program.\\n\\n\\nIn order to complete the 2016-2017&nbsp;application process and be considered for the NCSSM Class of 2019, potential applicants must complete ALL of the requirements within the required time frames:&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nStep 1: Determine If You Are Eligible\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nApplicants must currently be in the 10th grade.\\n\\t\\nIt is the policy of the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enroll only students who are legal residents of the State of North Carolina, as defined by G. S. 116.235, or whose parent or legal guardian is an active duty member of the armed services who is abiding in North Carolina incident to active military duty, provided the student shares the abode of that parent, by December 1 of the school year in which the student applies for admission (the 10th grade year) and who otherwise meet the admissions criteria of the School.\\n\\n\\n\\nStep 2:&nbsp;Complete an Application via CFNC.org\\n\\n\\nThe next application opens &nbsp;October 15, 2016\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nNCSSM has partnered with the College Foundation of North Carolina (CFNC) to create the NCSSM electronic application.&nbsp; To complete an application you must have a CFNC account.&nbsp; Go to&nbsp;www.cfnc.org&nbsp;read through the instructions and create a CFNC Account. &nbsp;Once you have created an account or if you already have a CFNC account:\\n\\n\\t\\nLog into CFNC.org.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nClick 'Apply\\&quot; and 'To College'\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nNext, click on 'Application Hub'\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nNow click on &nbsp;'Start an Application'\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nUse the search tool and type in 'NC' and select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu to start the application.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nUnder Intent to Apply use the drop-downs to indicate which program(s) you intend to apply to.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nYou can save the application and return to it as long as you submit it by the deadline.&nbsp;\\n\\t\\n\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nAll NCSSM Applications must be completed via the CFNC.org electronic application. There are no exceptions.\\n\\t\\nApplicants must have each section of the application completed by January 15, 2017. &nbsp;There are no exceptions to this deadline.\\n\\t\\nQuestions for determining residency are built into the electronic application, however, some applicants may be required to provide additional documentation and will be contacted by an Office of Admissions residency expert after their application has been submitted.\\n\\n\\n\\nNote: applicants will use this CFNC account to submit a transcript and monitor their admissions progress and status.\\n\\n\\nStep 3: Take the SAT by January 21, 2017\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nAll applicants must take the SAT as a sophomore as part of the application process. Applicants do not have to take the SAT before creating an application account.\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nNCSSM does not require the Essay portion of the new SAT.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nOnly score reports from tests administered on the following dates will be accepted:\\n\\t\\n\\t\\t\\nOctober 1, 2016\\n\\t\\t\\nNovember 5, 2016\\n\\t\\t\\nDecember 3, 2016\\n\\t\\t\\nJanuary 21, 2017\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nFor students requiring testing accommodations due to disabilities, please visit the following site as test registration and administration&nbsp;dates can vary:\\n\\t\\nhttp://www.collegeboard.org/students-with-disabilities/calendar\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nWe recommend that applicants register to take the SAT prior to the January test date. Test site cancellations due to inclement weather often occur during January.\\n\\t\\nTo ensure that test results are sent directly to the NCSSM Admissions Office, students using a hard copy of the SAT registration form must enter the NCSSM special code 2241 in Block 11A. Students registering online for the SAT must select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the list of schools, to send the score report.\\n\\n\\n\\nStep 4: Obtain Teacher &amp; Counselor Evaluations\\n\\n\\nFebruary 1 to March 15, 2017\\n\\n\\nPlease read the Evaluation&nbsp;Guidebook&nbsp;for Applicants if you have questions about the evaluation process.\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nAs part of the application process, applicants must secure evaluations from three teachers and his or her current guidance counselor. Applicants must have a teacher evaluation form completed by their:\\n\\t\\n\\t\\t\\n*9th or 10th grade Science Teacher\\n\\t\\t\\n*9th or 10th grade Mathematics Teacher\\n\\t\\t\\n*9th or 10th grade English Teacher\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nIt is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their teachers and counselor to complete an evaluation on their behalf and add that information in UniApp.\\n\\t\\nFebruary 1, 2017: Applicant/Family receive email notification that Teacher and Counselor Evaluation electronic link has been emailed, and teachers and counselors are granted access to the electronic form.\\n\\t\\nMarch 15, 2017: Deadline for receipt of Teacher and Counselor Evaluation Forms by NCSSM\\n\\t\\nTeacher Evaluation and Counselor Report Forms will be accessible in our evaluation website.\\n\\n\\n\\nStep 5: Submit a Transcript with Fall 2016&nbsp;Grades\\n\\n\\nMarch 1 to March 15, 2017\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nThe NCSSM Office of Admissions will accept transcripts from March 1&nbsp;until March 15&nbsp;\\n\\t\\nTo request a transcript using CFNC.org's Transcript Manager:\\n\\t\\n-- Log into CFNC.org\\n\\n\\t\\n-- Under the Apply Section, click 'To College,' and then 'Transcript Manager'\\n\\n\\t\\n-- Select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu\\n\\t\\n\\n\\n\\nRead more about submitting transcripts&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nStep 6: Attend Discovery Day (residential only)\\n\\nMust attend on the date assigned, by county&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nIn addition to the requirements listed above, all&nbsp;residential&nbsp;applicants are required to attend an assigned Discovery Day on the campus of NCSSM.\\n\\t\\nAll applicants MUST be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.\\n\\t\\nOn Discovery Day,&nbsp;residential&nbsp;applicants will take an NCSSM math test.\\n\\t\\nParents will attend an information session highlighting academics and student life.\\n\\t\\nDetails concerning Discovery Day will be emailed after students have&nbsp;completed and submitted their application.\\n\\n\\n\\nDiscovery Day I: February 18, 2017\\n\\n\\nDiscovery Day II: February 25, 2017\\n\\n\\nDiscovery Day III: March 4, 2017\\n\\n\\nFollow your progress&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nApplicants will be able to follow their progress during the admissions process using a secure, NCSSM web link. After the application deadline on January 15, 2017 and by January 19th at the latest, each applicant will be emailed a link and password to monitor their application process and final status. Applicants will be able to see whether or not their SATs and evaluations have been received and processed by NCSSM admissions.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;&quot;,&quot;blockGroups&quot;:{&quot;main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;rightColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;26593912232291567&quot;}]},&quot;main_26593912232291567_col1&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;884780406376900551&quot;}]},&quot;main_26593912232291567_col1_884780406376900551_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;422566355567294604&quot;}]}},&quot;rightColumn&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/residential-admissions:rightColumn&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;header&quot;:&quot;Residential his own words</h3>\\n\\n<div>Click to read why Braxton Baird '15, says &amp;quot;<a href=\\&quot;http://http://thetab.com/us/clemson/2016/02/22/choosing-ncssm-college-best-decision-349\\&quot;>Attending NCSSM before college was the best decision of my <strong>Admissions</strong></h2>\\n\\n<div>&nbsp;</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_301538449533593_headline&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/residential-admissions:main_301538449533593_headline&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<p><strong>Academics </strong>Admissions</p>\\n\\n<div>&nbsp;</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_26593912232291567_col1_884780406376900551_main_422566355567294604_col1&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/residential-admissions:main_26593912232291567_col1_884780406376900551_main_422566355567294604_col1&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;video&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;video&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w148897441791197405&quot;,&quot;video&quot;:&quot;https://youtu.be/OfOho04lfjs&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:&quot;https://i.ytimg.com/vi/OfOho04lfjs/hqdefault.jpg&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;What's the best thing about choosing NCSSM?&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/residential-admissions:main_26593912232291567_col1_884780406376900551_main_422566355567294604_col1.items.0.video&quot;},&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;captionedVideo&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h2>How to Apply</h2>\\n\\n<div>\\n<p>Eligible applicants may apply to either NCSSM's residential or online program, or both,&nbsp;using one electronic application.&nbsp;There is no cost to apply and no tuition for either program.</p>\\n\\n<p>In order to complete the 2016-2017&nbsp;application process and be considered for the NCSSM Class of 2019, potential applicants must complete ALL of the requirements within the required time frames:&nbsp;</p>\\n\\n<h3>Step 1: Determine If You Are Eligible</h3>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>Applicants must currently be in the 10th grade.</li>\\n\\t<li>It is the policy of the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enroll only students who are legal residents of the State of North Carolina, as defined by G. S. 116.235, or whose parent or legal guardian is an active duty member of the armed services who is abiding in North Carolina incident to active military duty, provided the student shares the abode of that parent, by December 1 of the school year in which the student applies for admission (the 10th grade year) and who otherwise meet the admissions criteria of the School.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3>Step 2:&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www1.cfnc.org/\\&quot;>Complete an Application via CFNC.org</a></h3>\\n\\n<p><strong>The next application opens &nbsp;October 15, 2016</strong></p>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>NCSSM has partnered with the College Foundation of North Carolina (CFNC) to create the NCSSM electronic application.&nbsp; To complete an application you must have a CFNC account.&nbsp; Go to&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;https://www1.cfnc.org/\\&quot; target=\\&quot;_blank\\&quot;>www.cfnc.org</a>&nbsp;read through the instructions and create a CFNC Account. &nbsp;Once you have created an account or if you already have a CFNC account:\\n\\n\\t<p>Log into CFNC.org.</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Click 'Apply&amp;quot; and 'To College'</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Next, click on 'Application Hub'</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Now click on &nbsp;'Start an Application'</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Use the search tool and type in 'NC' and select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu to start the application.</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Under Intent to Apply use the drop-downs to indicate which program(s) you intend to apply to.</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>You can save the application and return to it as long as you submit it by the deadline.&nbsp;</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>All NCSSM Applications must be completed via the CFNC.org electronic application. There are no exceptions.</li>\\n\\t<li>Applicants must have each section of the application completed by January 15, 2017. &nbsp;There are no exceptions to this deadline.</li>\\n\\t<li>Questions for determining residency are built into the electronic application, however, some applicants may be required to provide additional documentation and will be contacted by an Office of Admissions residency expert after their application has been submitted.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<p>Note: applicants will use this CFNC account to submit a transcript and monitor their admissions progress and status.</p>\\n\\n<h3>Step 3: Take the SAT by January 21, 2017</h3>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>All applicants must take the SAT as a sophomore as part of the application process. Applicants do not have to take the SAT before creating an application account.</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<div><strong>NCSSM does not require the Essay portion of the new SAT.</strong></div>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>Only score reports from tests administered on the following dates will be accepted:\\n\\t<ul>\\n\\t\\t<li>October 1, 2016</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>November 5, 2016</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>December 3, 2016</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>January 21, 2017</li>\\n\\t</ul>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>For students requiring testing accommodations due to disabilities, please visit the following site as test registration and administration&nbsp;dates can vary:\\n\\t<p><a href=\\&quot;http://www.collegeboard.org/students-with-disabilities/calendar\\&quot;>http://www.collegeboard.org/students-with-disabilities/calendar</a></p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>We recommend that applicants register to take the SAT prior to the January test date. Test site cancellations due to inclement weather often occur during January.</li>\\n\\t<li>To ensure that test results are sent directly to the NCSSM Admissions Office, students using a hard copy of the SAT registration form must enter the NCSSM special code 2241 in Block 11A. Students registering online for the SAT must select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the list of schools, to send the score report.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3>Step 4: Obtain Teacher &amp;amp; Counselor Evaluations</h3>\\n\\n<p><strong>February 1 to March 15, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<p>Please read the Evaluation&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://uniapp.ncssm.edu/forms/NCSSM%20Teacher%20and%20Counselor%20Evaluation%20Guide%20for%20Applicants.pdf\\&quot;>Guidebook</a>&nbsp;for Applicants if you have questions about the evaluation process.</p>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>As part of the application process, applicants must secure evaluations from three teachers and his or her current guidance counselor. Applicants must have a teacher evaluation form completed by their:\\n\\t<ul>\\n\\t\\t<li>*9th or 10th grade Science Teacher</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>*9th or 10th grade Mathematics Teacher</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>*9th or 10th grade English Teacher</li>\\n\\t</ul>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>It is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their teachers and counselor to complete an evaluation on their behalf and add that information in UniApp.</li>\\n\\t<li>February 1, 2017: Applicant/Family receive email notification that Teacher and Counselor Evaluation electronic link has been emailed, and teachers and counselors are granted access to the electronic form.</li>\\n\\t<li>March 15, 2017: Deadline for receipt of Teacher and Counselor Evaluation Forms by NCSSM</li>\\n\\t<li>Teacher Evaluation and Counselor Report Forms will be accessible in our evaluation website.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3>Step 5: Submit a Transcript with Fall 2016&nbsp;Grades</h3>\\n\\n<p><strong>March 1 to March 15, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>The NCSSM Office of Admissions will accept transcripts from March 1&nbsp;until March 15&nbsp;</li>\\n\\t<li>To request a transcript using CFNC.org's Transcript Manager:\\n\\t<p>-- Log into CFNC.org</p>\\n\\n\\t<p>-- Under the Apply Section, click 'To College,' and then 'Transcript Manager'</p>\\n\\n\\t<p>-- Select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<p><a href=\\&quot;http://uniapp.ncssm.edu/forms/Submit_Transcript.pdf\\&quot;>Read more about submitting transcripts&nbsp;</a></p>\\n\\n<h3>Step 6: Attend Discovery Day (residential only)<br />\\n<strong>Must attend on the date assigned, by county&nbsp;</strong></h3>\\n\\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>In addition to the requirements listed above, all&nbsp;residential&nbsp;applicants are required to attend an assigned Discovery Day on the campus of NCSSM.</li>\\n\\t<li>All applicants MUST be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.</li>\\n\\t<li>On Discovery Day,&nbsp;residential&nbsp;applicants will take an NCSSM math test.</li>\\n\\t<li>Parents will attend an information session highlighting academics and student life.</li>\\n\\t<li>Details concerning Discovery Day will be emailed after students have&nbsp;completed and submitted their application.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<p><strong>Discovery Day I: February 18, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Discovery Day II: February 25, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Discovery Day III: March 4, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<h3>Follow your progress&nbsp;</h3>\\n\\n<div>Applicants will be able to follow their progress during the admissions process using a secure, NCSSM web link. After the application deadline on January 15, 2017 and by January 19th at the latest, each applicant will be emailed a link and password to monitor their application process and final status. Applicants will be able to see whether or not their SATs and evaluations have been received and processed by NCSSM admissions.</div>\\n\\n<div>&nbsp;</div>\\n</div>\\n\\n<div>&nbsp;</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_26593912232291567_col1_668942978506686715_col1&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/residential-admissions:main_26593912232291567_col1_668942978506686715_col1&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;}}},{&quot;id&quot;:&quot;201980781511313159&quot;,&quot;sectionTitle&quot;:&quot;Online&quot;,&quot;pageId&quot;:&quot;474607010699778398&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Specialized throughout your student s time at ncssm from arriving on campus to academics and extracurriculars&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics Online&nbsp;\\n\\n\\noffers a supplemental, two-year, sequenced honors program&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nthat provides the NCSSM experience to students enrolled at&nbsp;\\n\\n\\ntheir local schools. NCSSM Online, begun in 2008, provides&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nvaluable preparation for college along with a learning&nbsp;\\n\\n\\ncommunity of accomplished, motivated peers.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nAn option that's often the best of two worlds&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nA growing number of North Carolina high school students are finding that staying enrolled in their current school while also taking challenging courses online at NCSSM offers is a great option — and one that catches the eyes of college admissions officers. NCSSM Online could be the&nbsp;perfect way to design your future.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nScience\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nEnvironmental Science\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;  \\nOnline Academics \\nStudent Life \\nMeet Our Students \\nFor Families&nbsp; \\n\\n\\nWe challenge what's possible\\n\\n\\nNCSSM Online&nbsp;offers a supplemental, two-year, sequenced honors program&nbsp;that provides for students who remain&nbsp;enrolled at&nbsp;their local schools. Begun in 2008, NCSSM Online provides valuable preparation for college along with a learning&nbsp;community of accomplished, motivated peers.\\n \\nJoin a supportive community\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nNCSSM Online courses include Saturday visits at the NCSSM campus once per semester.&nbsp;Students are encourage to participate in clubs and research activities. Many online students attend prom,&nbsp;where they can interact more with residential students. Understanding, respecting, and appreciating fellow students' differences and similarities is a value shared across programs.\\n \\nMeet our students\\n\\n\\nNCSSM Online&nbsp;students live and learn across&nbsp;the state.&nbsp;Meet some of our&nbsp;current students and hear from recent alumni about what their NCSSM experience so special. &nbsp; \\nBecome part of the community\\n\\n\\nOur families are part of the NCSSM community too! Here you'll find answers to many questions you may have throughout your student’s time at NCSSM, from arriving on campus to academics and challenge what's possible</h3>\\n\\n<p>NCSSM Online&nbsp;offers a supplemental, two-year, sequenced honors program&nbsp;that provides for students who remain&nbsp;enrolled at&nbsp;their local schools. Begun in 2008, NCSSM Online provides valuable preparation for college along with a learning&nbsp;community of accomplished, motivated peers.</p>\\n</div>&quot;},{&quot;text&quot;:&quot;Learn more about Online academics&quot;,&quot;linkType&quot;:&quot;internal&quot;,&quot;pageId&quot;:&quot;769133427494923227&quot;,&quot;link&quot;:null,&quot;color&quot;:&quot;btn-primary&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;btn-lg&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;btn-block&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;button&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_489952508443777913_main_20362410985669984_col2&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/online-program:main_489952508443777913_main_20362410985669984_col2&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h3>Join a supportive community</h3>\\n\\n<div>\\n<p>NCSSM Online courses include Saturday visits at the NCSSM campus once per semester.&nbsp;Students are encourage to participate in clubs and research activities. Many online students attend prom,&nbsp;where they can interact more with residential students. online admissions&quot;,&quot;highSearchWords&quot;:[&quot;admissions&quot;,&quot;online&quot;],&quot;lowSearchText&quot;:&quot;admissions online admissions download the online program profile below ncssm onlineprogram labs apchem and appliedchem engineering 2013 001 x3 how to apply if you re an eligible applicant you may apply to ncssm s residential and online program using one electronic application there is no cost to apply and no tuition for either program in order to complete the 2016 2017 application process and be considered for the ncssm class of 2019 potential applicants must complete all of the requirements within the required time frames step 1 determine if you are eligible applicants must currently be in the 10th grade it is the policy of the north carolina school of science and mathematics to enroll only students who are legal residents of the state of north carolina as defined by g s 116 143 1 or whose parent or legal guardian is an active duty member of the armed services who is abiding in north carolina incident to active military duty provided the student shares the abode of that parent by december 1 of the school year in which the student applies for admission the 10th grade year and who otherwise meet the admissions criteria of the school step 2 complete an application via cfnc org ncssm has partnered with the college foundation of north carolina cfnc to create the ncssm electronic application to complete an application you must have a cfnc account go to www cfnc org read through the instructions and create a cfnc account once you have created an account or if you already have a cfnc account log into cfnc org click apply and to college next click on application hub now click on start an application use the search tool and type in nc and select north carolina school of science and math from the pull down menu to start the application under intent to apply use the drop downs to indicate which program s you intend to apply to you can save the application and return to it as long as you submit it by the deadline all ncssm applications must be completed via the cfnc org electronic application there are no exceptions applicants must have each section of the application completed by january 15 2017 there are no exceptions to this deadline questions for determining residency are built into the electronic application however some applicants may be required to provide additional documentation and will be contacted by an office of admissions residency expert after their application has been submitted note applicants will use this cfnc account to submit a transcript and monitor their admissions progress and status step 3 take the sat by january 21 2017 all applicants must take the sat as a sophomore as part of the application process applicants do not have to take the sat before creating an application account only score reports from tests administered on the following dates will be accepted october 1 2016 november 5 2016 december 3 2016 january 21 2017 ncssm does not require the essay portion of the new sat for students requiring testing accommodations due to disabilities please visit the following site as test registration and administration dates can vary http www collegeboard org students with disabilities calendar we recommend that applicants register to take the sat prior to the january test date test site cancellations due to inclement weather often occur during january to ensure that test results are sent directly to the ncssm admissions office students using a hard copy of the sat registration form must enter the ncssm special code 2241 in block 11a students registering online for the sat must select north carolina school of science and math from the list of schools to send the score report step 4 obtain teacher counselor evaluations february 1 to march 15 2017 as part of the application process applicants must secure evaluations from three teachers and his or her current guidance counselor applicants must have a teacher evaluation form completed by their 9th or 10th grade science teacher 9th or 10th grade mathematics teacher 9th or 10th grade english teacher it is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their teachers and counselor to complete an evaluation on their behalf and add that information in uniapp february 1 2017 applicant family receive email notification that teacher and counselor evaluation electronic link has been emailed and teachers and counselors are granted access to the electronic form march 15 2017 deadline for receipt of teacher and counselor evaluation forms by ncssm teacher evaluation and counselor report forms will be accessible in an electronic format step 5 submit transcript with fall 2016 grades march 1 to march 15 2017 the ncssm office of admissions will accept transcripts from march 1 until march 15 to request a transcript using cfnc org s transcript manager log into cfnc org under the apply section click to college and then transcript manager select north carolina school of science and math from the pull down menu read more about submitting transcripts follow your progress applicants will be able to follow their progress during the admissions process using a secure ncssm web link after the application deadline on january 15 2017 each applicant will be emailed a link and password to monitor their application process and final status applicants will be able to see whether or not their sats and evaluations have been received and processed by ncssm admissions&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nDownload the Online Program Profile below:&nbsp; \\nHow to Apply\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nIf you're an eligible applicant, you&nbsp;may apply to NCSSM's residential and online program using one electronic application.&nbsp;There is no cost to apply and no tuition for either&nbsp;program.\\n\\n\\nIn order to complete the 2016-2017&nbsp;application process and be considered for the NCSSM Class of 2019, potential applicants must complete ALL of the requirements within the required time frames:\\n\\n\\nStep 1: Determine if you are eligible\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nApplicants must currently be in the 10th grade.\\n\\t\\nIt is the policy of the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enroll only students who are legal residents of the State of North Carolina, as defined by G. S. 116-143.1, or whose parent or legal guardian is an active duty member of the armed services who is abiding in North Carolina incident to active military duty, provided the student shares the abode of that parent, by December 1 of the school year in which the student applies for admission (the 10th grade year) and who otherwise meet the admissions criteria of the School.\\n\\n\\n\\nStep 2:&nbsp;Complete an application via CFNC.org\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nNCSSM has partnered with the College Foundation of North Carolina (CFNC) to create the NCSSM electronic application.&nbsp; To complete an application you must have a CFNC account.&nbsp; Go to&nbsp;www.cfnc.org&nbsp;read through the instructions and create a CFNC Account. &nbsp;Once you have created an account or if you already have a CFNC account:\\n\\n\\t\\nLog into CFNC.org.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nClick 'Apply\\&quot; and 'To College'\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nNext, click on 'Application Hub'\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nNow click on &nbsp;'Start an Application'\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nUse the search tool and type in 'NC' and select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu to start the application.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nUnder Intent to Apply use the drop-downs to indicate which program(s) you intend to apply to.\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nYou can save the application and return to it as long as you submit it by the deadline.&nbsp;\\n\\t\\n\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nAll NCSSM Applications must be completed via the CFNC.org electronic application. There are no exceptions.\\n\\t\\nApplicants must have each section of the application completed by January 15, 2017. &nbsp;There are no exceptions to this deadline.\\n\\t\\nQuestions for determining residency are built into the electronic application, however, some applicants may be required to provide additional documentation and will be contacted by an Office of Admissions residency expert after their application has been submitted.\\n\\n\\n\\nNote: applicants will use this CFNC account to submit a transcript and monitor their admissions progress and status.\\n\\n\\nStep 3: Take the SAT by January 21, 2017&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nAll applicants must take the SAT as a sophomore as part of the application process. Applicants do not have to take the SAT before creating an application account.\\n\\n\\n\\t\\n\\n\\t\\nOnly score reports from tests administered on the following dates will be accepted:\\n\\n\\t\\n\\t\\t\\nOctober 1, 2016\\n\\t\\t\\nNovember 5, 2016\\n\\t\\t\\nDecember 3, 2016\\n\\t\\t\\nJanuary 21, 2017&nbsp;\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nNCSSM does not require the Essay portion of the new SAT.\\n\\t\\nFor students requiring testing accommodations due to disabilities, please visit the following site as test registration and administration&nbsp;dates can vary:\\n\\t\\nhttp://www.collegeboard.org/students-with-disabilities/calendar\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nWe recommend that applicants register to take the SAT prior to the January test date. Test site cancellations due to inclement weather often occur during January.\\n\\t\\nTo ensure that test results are sent directly to the NCSSM Admissions Office, students using a hard copy of the SAT registration form must enter the NCSSM special code 2241 in Block 11A. Students registering online for the SAT must select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the list of schools, to send the score report.\\n\\n\\n\\nStep 4: Obtain teacher &amp; counselor evaluations\\n\\n\\nFebruary 1 to March 15, 2017\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nAs part of the application process, applicants must secure evaluations from three teachers and his or her current guidance counselor. Applicants must have a teacher evaluation form completed by their:\\n\\t\\n\\t\\t\\n*9th or 10th grade Science Teacher\\n\\t\\t\\n*9th or 10th grade Mathematics Teacher\\n\\t\\t\\n*9th or 10th grade English Teacher\\n\\t\\n\\t\\n\\t\\nIt is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their teachers and counselor to complete an evaluation on their behalf and add that information in UniApp.\\n\\t\\nFebruary 1, 2017: Applicant/Family receive email notification that Teacher and Counselor Evaluation electronic link has been emailed, and teachers and counselors are granted access to the electronic form.\\n\\t\\nMarch 15, 2017: Deadline for receipt of Teacher and Counselor Evaluation Forms by NCSSM\\n\\t\\nTeacher Evaluation and Counselor Report Forms will be accessible in an electronic format\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nStep 5: Submit&nbsp;transcript&nbsp;with&nbsp;fall&nbsp;2016&nbsp;&nbsp;grades\\n\\n\\nMarch 1 to March 15, 2017\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nThe NCSSM Office of Admissions will accept transcripts from March 1&nbsp;until March 15&nbsp;\\n\\t\\nTo request a transcript using CFNC.org's Transcript Manager:\\n\\t\\n-- Log into CFNC.org\\n\\n\\t\\n-- Under the Apply Section, click 'To College,' and then 'Transcript Manager'\\n\\n\\t\\n-- Select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu\\n\\t\\n\\n\\n\\nRead more about submitting transcripts&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nFollow your progress&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nApplicants will be able to follow their progress during the admissions process using a secure, NCSSM web link. After the application deadline on January 15, 2017, each applicant will be emailed a link and password to monitor their application process and final status. Applicants will be able to see whether or not their SATs and evaluations have been received and processed by NCSSM admissions.&nbsp;\\n&quot;,&quot;blockGroups&quot;:{&quot;main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;rightColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;29877559057089899&quot;}]},&quot;main_29877559057089899_col1&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;76669098879905613&quot;}]},&quot;main_29877559057089899_col1_76669098879905613_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;493508684689696572&quot;}]},&quot;main_29877559057089899_col1_303445539649584054_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[]}},&quot;rightColumn&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/online-admissions:rightColumn&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;header&quot;:&quot;Online
