online&quot;,&quot;online students&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;121&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;127&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1276&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;170&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;262&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;964&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;702&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;378&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;121&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;222&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;214&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:170,&quot;left&quot;:262,&quot;width&quot;:964,&quot;height&quot;:702}}]},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h2>How to Apply</h2>\\n\\n<div>\\n<p>If you're an eligible applicant, you&nbsp;may apply to NCSSM's residential and online program using one electronic application.&nbsp;There is no cost to apply and no tuition for either&nbsp;program.</p>\\n\\n<p>In order to complete the 2016-2017&nbsp;application process and be considered for the NCSSM Class of 2019, potential applicants must complete ALL of the requirements within the required time frames:</p>\\n\\n<h3>Step 1: Determine if you are eligible</h3>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>Applicants must currently be in the 10th grade.</li>\\n\\t<li>It is the policy of the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enroll only students who are legal residents of the State of North Carolina, as defined by G. S. 116-143.1, or whose parent or legal guardian is an active duty member of the armed services who is abiding in North Carolina incident to active military duty, provided the student shares the abode of that parent, by December 1 of the school year in which the student applies for admission (the 10th grade year) and who otherwise meet the admissions criteria of the School.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3>Step 2:&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www1.cfnc.org/\\&quot;>Complete an application via CFNC.org</a></h3>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>NCSSM has partnered with the College Foundation of North Carolina (CFNC) to create the NCSSM electronic application.&nbsp; To complete an application you must have a CFNC account.&nbsp; Go to&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;https://www1.cfnc.org/\\&quot; target=\\&quot;_blank\\&quot;>www.cfnc.org</a>&nbsp;read through the instructions and create a CFNC Account. &nbsp;Once you have created an account or if you already have a CFNC account:\\n\\n\\t<p>Log into CFNC.org.</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Click 'Apply&amp;quot; and 'To College'</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Next, click on 'Application Hub'</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Now click on &nbsp;'Start an Application'</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Use the search tool and type in 'NC' and select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu to start the application.</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>Under Intent to Apply use the drop-downs to indicate which program(s) you intend to apply to.</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<p>You can save the application and return to it as long as you submit it by the deadline.&nbsp;</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>All NCSSM Applications must be completed via the CFNC.org electronic application. There are no exceptions.</li>\\n\\t<li>Applicants must have each section of the application completed by January 15, 2017. &nbsp;There are no exceptions to this deadline.</li>\\n\\t<li>Questions for determining residency are built into the electronic application, however, some applicants may be required to provide additional documentation and will be contacted by an Office of Admissions residency expert after their application has been submitted.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<p>Note: applicants will use this CFNC account to submit a transcript and monitor their admissions progress and status.</p>\\n\\n<h3>Step 3: Take the SAT by January 21, 2017&nbsp;</h3>\\n\\n<div>All applicants must take the SAT as a sophomore as part of the application process. Applicants do not have to take the SAT before creating an application account.</div>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>\\n\\t<div>Only score reports from tests administered on the following dates will be accepted:</div>\\n\\n\\t<ul>\\n\\t\\t<li>October 1, 2016</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>November 5, 2016</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>December 3, 2016</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>January 21, 2017&nbsp;</li>\\n\\t</ul>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li><strong>NCSSM does not require the Essay portion of the new SAT.</strong></li>\\n\\t<li>For students requiring testing accommodations due to disabilities, please visit the following site as test registration and administration&nbsp;dates can vary:\\n\\t<p><a href=\\&quot;http://www.collegeboard.org/students-with-disabilities/calendar\\&quot;>http://www.collegeboard.org/students-with-disabilities/calendar</a></p>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>We recommend that applicants register to take the SAT prior to the January test date. Test site cancellations due to inclement weather often occur during January.</li>\\n\\t<li>To ensure that test results are sent directly to the NCSSM Admissions Office, students using a hard copy of the SAT registration form must enter the NCSSM special code 2241 in Block 11A. Students registering online for the SAT must select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the list of schools, to send the score report.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3>Step 4: Obtain teacher &amp;amp; counselor evaluations</h3>\\n\\n<p><strong>February 1 to March 15, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>As part of the application process, applicants must secure evaluations from three teachers and his or her current guidance counselor. Applicants must have a teacher evaluation form completed by their:\\n\\t<ul>\\n\\t\\t<li>*9th or 10th grade Science Teacher</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>*9th or 10th grade Mathematics Teacher</li>\\n\\t\\t<li>*9th or 10th grade English Teacher</li>\\n\\t</ul>\\n\\t</li>\\n\\t<li>It is the responsibility of the applicant to ask their teachers and counselor to complete an evaluation on their behalf and add that information in UniApp.</li>\\n\\t<li>February 1, 2017: Applicant/Family receive email notification that Teacher and Counselor Evaluation electronic link has been emailed, and teachers and counselors are granted access to the electronic form.</li>\\n\\t<li>March 15, 2017: Deadline for receipt of Teacher and Counselor Evaluation Forms by NCSSM</li>\\n\\t<li>Teacher Evaluation and Counselor Report Forms will be accessible in an electronic format</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3><br />\\nStep 5: Submit&nbsp;transcript&nbsp;with&nbsp;fall&nbsp;2016&nbsp;&nbsp;grades</h3>\\n\\n<p><strong>March 1 to March 15, 2017</strong></p>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>The NCSSM Office of Admissions will accept transcripts from March 1&nbsp;until March 15&nbsp;</li>\\n\\t<li>To request a transcript using CFNC.org's Transcript Manager:\\n\\t<p>-- Log into CFNC.org</p>\\n\\n\\t<p>-- Under the Apply Section, click 'To College,' and then 'Transcript Manager'</p>\\n\\n\\t<p>-- Select North Carolina School of Science and Math from the pull down menu</p>\\n\\t</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<p><a href=\\&quot;http://www.ncssm.edu/apply/transcripts\\&quot; target=\\&quot;_blank\\&quot;>Read more about submitting transcripts</a>&nbsp;</p>\\n\\n<h3>Follow your progress&nbsp;</h3>\\n\\n<p>Applicants will be able to follow their progress during the admissions process using a secure, NCSSM web link. After the application deadline on January 15, 2017, each applicant will be emailed a link and password to monitor their application process and final status. Applicants will be able to see whether or not their SATs and evaluations have been received and processed by NCSSM admissions.&nbsp;</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;}}},{&quot;id&quot;:&quot;316265734726072529&quot;,&quot;sectionTitle&quot;:&quot;Summer&quot;,&quot;pageId&quot;:&quot;953455891635543761&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;For graders, underrepresented minorities\\n\\t\\nWeek-long residential program on our Durham campus in July\\n\\t\\nNo cost to participants\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nSummer Accelerator \\n\\n\\nSummer Accelerator&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n\\t\\nFor rising 10th-12th graders; Early Accelerator for rising 7th-9th graders\\n\\t\\nResidential program on our Durham campus, paired with some online University\\n\\t\\nPrograms run between mid-June and early August, depending on site\\n\\t\\nNo cost to participants\\n\\n \\nExplore summer at NCSSM\\n\\n\\nNCSSM offers summer programs for students who are rising 7th graders through high school seniors, with&nbsp;specialized coursework in areas such as robotics, aviation technology, forensics, and computational chemistry. the Summer Programs Coordinator, I have been charged with developing the school's first program open to students from outside the state of North Carolina, and even beyond the United States. My experience with international affairs and programming spans managing international summer programs for high school students to directing a non-profit in Kenya. I have personally experienced, and witnessed, the transformative education made possible by summer programming and both study and experiences abroad. As the Summer Programs Coordinator, I am the point person for families and students through the Summer Accelerator's application and admissions process, and am on site through the summer. I support all summer activities in various ways.\\n\\nBA, Anthropology, Ohio University\\nMA, International Affairs, The New School - New refund including the deposit amount&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nSummer Accelerator/Early Accelerator Admissions\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nKey Dates\\n\\n\\nNovember&nbsp;1 5\\n\\nEarly registration&nbsp;for Accelerator alumni begins\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nDecember 1\\n\\nGeneral registration begins\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nFebruary 15, 2017\\n\\nLast day to receive $100 discount for paying in full&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nApril 1, 2017\\n\\nTuition is due.\\n\\n\\nfor anyone who applies and is accepted after April 1, 2017, tuition is due within two weeks of acceptance.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nEarly Accelerator Dates &amp; Courses (rising 7 - 9):\\nJune 11 - 16; Digital Design | Life, the Cosmos, and Everything | Math Problem Solving | Robotics | Young Builders.\\n\\n\\n\\nJune 18 - 23; Digital Design | Engineering Explorations | Epidemiology | Young Builders\\n\\n\\n\\nJuly 9 - 14;&nbsp;Ecological Research | Engineering for Young Women | Investigative Science | Math Problem Solving\\n\\n\\nAccelerator Dates &amp; Courses\\n\\n(rising 10 - 12):\\nJune 12 - 23 online; June 25 - 30 on campus; Advanced Cloning Lab |&nbsp;Epigenetics | Science Communicators | Math for Decision Making\\n\\n\\n\\nJuly 3 - 14 online; July 16 - 21 on campus; Advanced Cloning Lab | Cryptography | Epigentics | Mechatronics | Neuroscience\\n\\n\\n\\nJuly 10 - 21 online; July 23 - 28 on campus; Cryptography | Food Science | Neuroscience&nbsp; | Rocketry \\nWho can apply?\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nAccelerator and Early Accelerator courses are for exceptional rising 7th through 12th graders. Any student who meets the requirements for a particular course may apply for that course. Applicants do not have to be residents of North Carolina — students from all over the globe are encouraged to apply.\\n\\n\\nApplications must be completed by the prospective participant. Applicants should be thoughtful in their responses. The application will take between 30 – 60 minutes to complete. Please be sure to provide correct email addresses for both the participant and the parent contact. Applicants are asked to rank the courses for which they are applying and about their interest and experience with the course topic on the application.\\n\\n\\nWhen will I learn if I'm accepted?\\n\\n\\nStudents will be notified about their acceptance two to three weeks after submitting their application.\\n\\n\\nStudents in the NCSSM Online program are eligible for tuition awards. They should fill out the online application and&nbsp;will be notified of their acceptance in two to three weeks. Any NCSSM Online student who is accepted will receive an award.\\n\\n\\nHow much does the program cost?\\n\\n\\nTuition for Early Accelerator is $1,495, with a $1,320 day-only&nbsp;option.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nTuition for Accelerator is $1,925, with a $1,750 day-only option.\\n\\n\\nTuition for overnight students includes room and board for the on-campus portion of the course (breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snacks), as well as shuttle transportation from the airport, bus, or train station if needed. Tuition does not include transportation to and from Durham, North Carolina.\\n\\n\\nOnce a participant has been accepted into the program, a non-refundable deposit of $250 is&nbsp;due within seven days of acceptance to&nbsp;reserve the student’s spot. Those who register and pay in full by February 15, 2017, will receive a $100 discount. Final payment of tuition is due April 1st, 2017. Tuition is due within two weeks of acceptance for anyone who applies and is accepted after April 1st, 2017.\\n\\n\\nDiscounts are also available for students&nbsp;who register for two or more weeks over the same summer and for siblings who are both accepted and register for courses.\\n\\n\\nWhat if I am a current NCSSM Online Student?\\n\\n\\nStudents in the Online Program at NCSSM ae eligible for tuition awards. Those who submit their application by March 1, 2017,&nbsp; will be notified of their acceptance by March 15, 2017. After March 15th, Onine students are still eligible to apply and will be notified of acceptance on a rolling basis. The award covers full tuition, room, and board.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nIs there financial aid available?\\n\\n\\nWe will have more aid available for the summer of 2017. We recommend signing up for our mailing list to remain aware of our financial aid opportunities. You can subscribe here.\\n\\n\\nWhen is the deadline to apply?\\n\\n\\nApplications are accepted until courses begin. We will&nbsp;accept students until each course is full and, after that, add accepted applicants to a waitlist.\\n\\n\\nWhat if I have to cancel?\\n\\n\\nCancellations prior to 60 days before the start of the online portion of the course will receive a full&nbsp;tuition refund, minus the $250 deposit. Cancellations between 60 and 15 days before the start of the online portion of the course will receive 50% of the tuition refunded less the deposit. Cancellations within 15 days before the start of the online portion of the course will not receive a refund.\\n\\n\\nIn the case that the minimum requirements for running the program are not met, we reserve the right to cancel a course at any time, and will provide registered participants a full refund, including the deposit amount.\\n&quot;,&quot;blockGroups&quot;:{&quot;main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;120306435584331099&quot;},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;rightColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;686902866337126888&quot;}]},&quot;main_686902866337126888_col1&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;box&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;345980653155630565&quot;}]},&quot;main_686902866337126888_col1_345980653155630565_main&quot;:{&quot;blocks&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;oneColumn&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;839902188822492746&quot;}]}},&quot;main_500352263439679464_sectionHeader&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/summer-programs/accelerator/admissions:main_500352263439679464_sectionHeader&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h2>Summer the Summer Programs Coordinator, I have been charged with developing the school's first program open to students from outside the state of North Carolina, and even beyond the United States. My experience with international affairs and programming spans managing international summer programs for high school students to directing a non-profit in Kenya. I have personally experienced, and witnessed, the transformative education made possible by summer programming and both study and experiences abroad. As the Summer Programs Coordinator, I am the point person for families and students through the Summer Accelerator's application and admissions process, and am on site through the summer. I support all summer activities in various ways.\\n\\nBA, Anthropology, Ohio University\\nMA, International Affairs, The New School - New accelerator laugh none summer accelerator none jpg images jpeg jen hill&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;906656673265633362&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;summer accelerator&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false}]},{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h3><strong>Who can apply?</strong></h3>\\n\\n<div>\\n<p>Accelerator and Early Accelerator courses are for exceptional rising 7th through 12th graders. Any student who meets the requirements for a particular course may apply for that course. Applicants do not have to be residents of North Carolina — students from all over the globe are encouraged to apply.</p>\\n\\n<p>Applications must be completed by the prospective participant. Applicants should be thoughtful in their responses. The application will take between 30 – 60 minutes to complete. Please be sure to provide correct email addresses for both the participant and the parent contact. Applicants are asked to rank the courses for which they are applying and about their interest and experience with the course topic on the application.</p>\\n\\n<h3><strong>When will I learn if I'm accepted?</strong></h3>\\n\\n<p>Students will be notified about their acceptance two to three weeks after submitting their application.</p>\\n\\n<p>Students in the NCSSM Online program are eligible for tuition awards. They should fill out the online application and&nbsp;will be notified of their acceptance in two to three weeks. Any NCSSM Online student who is accepted will receive an award.</p>\\n\\n<h3>How much does the program cost?</h3>\\n\\n<p>Tuition for Early Accelerator is $1,495, with a $1,320 day-only&nbsp;option.&nbsp;</p>\\n\\n<p>Tuition for Accelerator is $1,925, with a $1,750 day-only option.</p>\\n\\n<p>Tuition for overnight students includes room and board for the on-campus portion of the course (breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snacks), as well as shuttle transportation from the airport, bus, or train station if needed. Tuition does not include transportation to and from Durham, North Carolina.</p>\\n\\n<p>Once a participant has been accepted into the program, a non-refundable deposit of $250 is&nbsp;due within seven days of acceptance to&nbsp;reserve the student’s spot. Those who register and pay in full by February 15, 2017, will receive a $100 discount. Final payment of tuition is due April 1st, 2017. <strong>Tuition is due within two weeks of acceptance for anyone who applies and is accepted after April 1st, 2017.</strong></p>\\n\\n<p>Discounts are also available for students&nbsp;who register for two or more weeks over the same summer and for siblings who are both accepted and register for courses.</p>\\n\\n<h3><strong>What if I am a current NCSSM Online Student?</strong></h3>\\n\\n<p>Students in the Online Program at NCSSM ae eligible for tuition awards. Those who submit their application by March 1, 2017,&nbsp; will be notified of their acceptance by March 15, 2017. After March 15th, Onine students are still eligible to apply and will be notified of acceptance on a rolling basis. The award covers full tuition, room, and board.&nbsp;</p>\\n\\n<h3>Is there financial aid available?</h3>\\n\\n<p>We will have more aid available for the summer of 2017. We recommend signing up for our mailing list to remain aware of our financial aid opportunities. You can <a href=\\&quot;http://eepurl.com/_K6UD\\&quot;>subscribe here</a>.</p>\\n\\n<h3><strong>When is the deadline to apply?</strong></h3>\\n\\n<p>Applications are accepted until courses begin. We will&nbsp;accept students until each course is full and, after that, add accepted applicants to a waitlist.</p>\\n\\n<h3>What if I have to cancel?</h3>\\n\\n<p>Cancellations prior to 60 days before the start of the online portion of the course will receive a full&nbsp;tuition refund, minus the $250 deposit. Cancellations between 60 and 15 days before the start of the online portion of the course will receive 50% of the tuition refunded less the deposit. Cancellations within 15 days before the start of the online portion of the course will not receive a refund.</p>\\n\\n<p>In the case that the minimum requirements for running the program are not met, we reserve the right to cancel a course at any time, and will provide registered participants a full refund, including the deposit amount.</p>\\n</div>&quot;},{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;editView&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;gallery&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w99761273758005036&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[],&quot;extras&quot;:{},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_120306435584331099_col1&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/summer-programs/accelerator/admissions:main_120306435584331099_col1&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;editView&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;gallery&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w161234963891207455&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;530674918211819092&quot;,&quot;74237314691456712&quot;,&quot;484939528296202837&quot;,&quot;187226285716446425&quot;,&quot;309577372809013257&quot;,&quot;209507311838526013&quot;,&quot;246351325965970652&quot;,&quot;737429830492408687&quot;,&quot;874529856142563653&quot;,&quot;466532093864163527&quot;,&quot;58643441590260142&quot;,&quot;336482672677792055&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;530674918211819092&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false},&quot;74237314691456712&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false},&quot;484939528296202837&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false},&quot;187226285716446425&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false},&quot;309577372809013257&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:96,&quot;left&quot;:306,&quot;width&quot;:1713,&quot;height&quot;:1239}},&quot;209507311838526013&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:fals forms of summer program content and developed custom curricula for schools and teachers across the state&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nAdvancing public education across North Carolina and beyond \\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\n&nbsp; \\nNC Public Schools\\n\\n\\nNCSSM works hand-in-hand with schools across North Carolina, partnering with the state's outstanding educators and calling on these to help with professional development initiatives hosted on our campus. NCSSM is one of eleven North Carolina Mathematics and Science Education Network &nbsp;Centers that form a network across the state with a common purpose of strengthening K-12 science and mathematics instruction.&nbsp; \\nYou care about education and want to advance learning innovations to meet the needs of&nbsp;bright young students. Let's talk about how we can tailor our resources to meet your community's needs. \\n&nbsp;NC Public Schools \\nSome text about how great the schools are&nbsp; \\nNorth Carolina Public Schools\\n\\n\\nNCSSM works hand-in-hand with schools across North Carolina, partnering to meet the needs of Local Education Agencies and individual students with courses and other support.&nbsp;NCSSM is one of eleven North Carolina Mathematics and Science Education Network Centers that form a network across the state with a common purpose of strengthening K-12 science and mathematics instruction.&nbsp; \\nNorth Carolina Public Schools\\n\\n\\nNCSSM works hand-in-hand with schools across North Carolina, partnering to meet the needs of Local Education Agencies and individual students with courses and other support.&nbsp;NCSSM is one of eleven North Carolina Mathematics and Science Education Network Centers that form a network across the state with a common purpose of strengthening K-12 science and mathematics instruction.&nbsp;&nbsp; \\nFor Educators\\n\\n\\nPartnering with outstanding educators across the state, NCSSM hosts professional development initiatives. Educators share teaching ideas, lesson plans, and materials through the blog, \\&quot;Learning Innovation.\\&quot; And we invite teachers to bring students to a number of conferences and events on campus throughout the school year.&nbsp; \\nPartner With Us\\n\\n\\nYou care about education and want to advance learning innovations to meet the needs of&nbsp;bright young students. Let's talk about how we can tailor our resources to meet your community's needs.&nbsp; \\nNorth Carolina Public Schools \\nPartnerships with NC Public Schools\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nNCSSM works hand-in-hand with schools across North Carolina, partnering to meet the needs of Local Education Agencies and individual students with courses and other support.&nbsp;NCSSM is one of eleven North Carolina Mathematics and Science Education Network Centers that form a network across the state with a common purpose of strengthening K-12 science and mathematics instruction.&nbsp; \\nFor Educators&nbsp; \\nResources and events for educators\\n\\n\\nPartnering with outstanding educators across the state, NCSSM hosts professional development initiatives. Educators share teaching ideas, lesson plans, and materials through the blog, \\&quot;Learning Innovations.\\&quot; And we invite teachers to bring students to a number of conferences and events on campus throughout the school year. &nbsp;&nbsp; \\nPartner with us\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nPartner With Us\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nLet's talk about how to work together\\n\\n\\nYou care about education and want to advance learning innovations to meet the needs of&nbsp;bright young students. Let's talk about how we can tailor our resources to meet your community's needs.&nbsp;&nbsp; \\nOur goal: Reaching 100,000 North Carolina teachers\\n\\nand&nbsp;1 million students by 2017\\n\\n\\n\\n\\nThrough extensive offerings in distance education and special programs, North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics partners with communities and regions across the state and beyond&nbsp;to advance student learning and outcomes. By listening to the needs of local education agencies, NCSSM has provided technical assistance for building future-ready classrooms, offered multiple forms of summer program content, and developed custom curricula for schools and teachers across the County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith Woofter&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;aspectRatio&quot;:[18,21],&quot;userOptions&quot;:{&quot;disableTitles&quot;:true,&quot;disableDescriptions&quot;:true,&quot;disableCredits&quot;:true},&quot;itemType&quot;:{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Image(s)&quot;,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;icon-image&quot;,&quot;css&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;},&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w298655967647076180&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;29248968681278945&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;29248968681278945&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;29248968681278945&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-28T01:45:41.637Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;2015-08-25-21-33-38-x3&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news (Thomas Wright '16)\\n\\n\\nTimes-News:&nbsp;Recent alumnus discusses gap year, humanitarian relief effort in Nepal&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nCBS Sunday Morning: The roots of Rhiannon Giddens '95\\n\\n\\nGlamour Magazine: Astronaut Christine Hammock Koch '97 sets eyes on Mars\\n\\n\\nNews &amp; Observer: Kelly Zhang '16 readies for national math contest with $10K prize\\n\\n\\nHigher Education Works: Doubling down on a winning innovation at NCSSM\\n\\n\\nForbes: Alumnus named to \\&quot;30 Under 30\\&quot; in healthcare&quot;,&quot;withTags&quot;:[],&quot;notTags&quot;:[],&quot;sortViews&quot;:0,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[0]},&quot;url&quot;:&quot;/news/2015/07/22/grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;main_35199405138312102_main_42535360962253394_col1&quot;:{&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/for-educators:main_35199405138312102_main_42535360962253394_col1&quot;,&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<h2>Our goal: Reaching 100,000 North Carolina teachers<br />\\nand&nbsp;1 million students by 2017</h2>\\n\\n<div>\\n<p>Through extensive offerings in distance education and special programs, North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics partners with communities and regions across the state and beyond&nbsp;to advance student learning and outcomes. By listening to the needs of local education agencies, NCSSM has provided technical assistance for building future-ready classrooms, offered multiple forms of summer program content, and developed custom curricula for schools and teachers across the state.</p>\\n\\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;},&quot;children&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;656346013569461500&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;NC Public public Grade 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news Woofter&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;aspectRatio&quot;:[18,21],&quot;userOptions&quot;:{&quot;disableTitles&quot;:true,&quot;disableDescriptions&quot;:true,&quot;disableCredits&quot;:true},&quot;itemType&quot;:{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Image(s)&quot;,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;icon-image&quot;,&quot;css&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;},&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w298655967647076180&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;29248968681278945&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;29248968681278945&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;29248968681278945&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-28T01:45:41.637Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;2015-08-25-21-33-38-x3&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news hensley in studio&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;fbd1cac889e9f64c71fd277e3b99d8ad&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:960,&quot;height&quot;:720,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;11954734 677996648999557 9081184316051837469 n beth hensley in studio none beth hensley durham public schools distance education school partnerships none jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;beth hensley&quot;,&quot;durham public schools&quot;,&quot;distance education&quot;,&quot;school partnerships&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;171&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;617&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;720&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;115&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;6&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;954&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;484&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;167&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;600&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;352&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;410&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:167,&quot;left&quot;:600,&quot;width&quot;:352,&quot;height&quot;:410}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>\\n<p>Each day, Durham Public Schools teacher Elizabeth Hensley comes to the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics campus to connect with a group of advanced middle school students at a handful of schools around Durham, thanks to NCSSM’s interactive videoconferencing studios. The partnership between the Durham schools and NCSSM offers a proof-of-concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology. NCSSM works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools, says Ross White, director of distance education at NCSSM.</p>\\n\\n<p>This is the first year of the Durham middle school program, which aims to “support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade,” explains Elizabeth Cross, director of advanced academics at Durham Public Schools. “It is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth, seventh, and eighth grades — bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace.”</p>\\n\\n<p>To determine how to best serve those “high flyers,” as Cross describes the students, she identified four students who were predicted to do well in Math 1 at the highest level. But those students are enrolled at four different schools. So Durham Public Schools turned to NCSSM’s distance education studios. “The teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience,” says Cross.</p>\\n\\n<p>The program launched during the first week of classes this fall. So far it has been a big success, says Cross. “This is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program. Parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students’ academic needs are met.&nbsp;The&nbsp;students&nbsp;are able to move through the curriculum at a faster pace than they would be able to do in a regular math class. At the same time, they are collaborating with others across the district. This is real twenty-first-century learning at work.”</p>\\n&nbsp;</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;studio helps serve advanced middle schoolers&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-25T21:27:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:612,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[612],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;studio helps serve advanced turned to ncssm s distance education studios the teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience says cross the program launched during the work&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\n\\n\\nEach day, Durham Public Schools teacher Elizabeth Hensley comes to the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics campus to connect with a group of advanced middle school students at a handful of schools around Durham, thanks to NCSSM’s interactive videoconferencing studios. The partnership between the Durham schools and NCSSM offers a proof-of-concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology. NCSSM works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools, says Ross White, director of distance education at NCSSM.\\n\\n\\nThis is the first year of the Durham middle school program, which aims to “support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade,” explains Elizabeth Cross, director of advanced academics at Durham Public Schools. “It is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth, seventh, and eighth grades — bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace.”\\n\\n\\nTo determine how to best serve those “high flyers,” as Cross describes the students, she identified four students who were predicted to do well in Math 1 at the highest level. But those students are enrolled at four different schools. So Durham Public Schools turned to NCSSM’s distance education studios. “The teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience,” says Cross.\\n\\n\\nThe program launched during the first week of classes this fall. So far it has been a big success, says Cross. “This is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program. Parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students’ academic needs are met.&nbsp;The&nbsp;students&nbsp;are able to move through the curriculum at a faster pace than they would be able to do in a regular math class. At the same time, they are collaborating with others across the district. This is real twenty-first-century learning at work.”\\n&nbsp;&quot;,&quot;_category&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;684891561223034135&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;category&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-07T17:52:05.012Z&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;On Woofter&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;aspectRatio&quot;:[18,21],&quot;userOptions&quot;:{&quot;disableTitles&quot;:true,&quot;disableDescriptions&quot;:true,&quot;disableCredits&quot;:true},&quot;itemType&quot;:{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Image(s)&quot;,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;icon-image&quot;,&quot;css&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;},&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w298655967647076180&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;29248968681278945&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;29248968681278945&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;29248968681278945&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-28T01:45:41.637Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;2015-08-25-21-33-38-x3&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction
