assessments for the past two years student scores have been lower than the state s overall composite scores students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period by partnering with ncssm the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity we re striving to perform better in every subject but we especially have to perform better in math says northampton county schools superintendent monica smith woofter who attended northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent this partnership with ncssm and the jack kent cooke foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal i believe in our students and i believe in our teachers and i know the great things we are capable of northampton county is one of those places where some exciting things are happening ncssm dean of distance education jamie lathan north carolina school of science and mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school s interactive videoconferencing studios in durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course northampton county schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies north carolina has a lot of potential a lot of intellectual capital that given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel could really make a huge positive impact on the state s future says jamie lathan dean of distance education at ncssm northampton county is one of those places where some exciting things are happening the school leaders from the superintendent s office to teachers in the classrooms are committed to the development of their students we re excited to be partnering with them on this program and we re especially grateful to the jack kent cooke foundation for their support jack kent cooke foundation the jack kent cooke foundation is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need by offering the largest scholarships in the country comprehensive counseling and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school the foundation is dedicated to ensuring high performing low income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally in addition to its scholarship programs the foundation provides grants for innovative high impact initiatives that benefit such students by doing so the cooke foundation seeks to use its resources to end the excellence gap the disparity between the number of low and high income students who reach the top levels of academic performance founded in 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith Woofter&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;aspectRatio&quot;:[18,21],&quot;userOptions&quot;:{&quot;disableTitles&quot;:true,&quot;disableDescriptions&quot;:true,&quot;disableCredits&quot;:true},&quot;itemType&quot;:{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Image(s)&quot;,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;icon-image&quot;,&quot;css&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;},&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w298655967647076180&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;29248968681278945&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;29248968681278945&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;29248968681278945&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-28T01:45:41.637Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;2015-08-25-21-33-38-x3&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools undefined grant boosts math instruction in high need schools nc public schools northampton county schools school partnerships grant boosts math instruction in high need schools northampton county schools superintendent monica smith woofter&quot;,&quot;highSearchWords&quot;:[&quot;grant&quot;,&quot;boosts&quot;,&quot;math&quot;,&quot;instruction&quot;,&quot;in&quot;,&quot;high&quot;,&quot;need&quot;,&quot;schools&quot;,&quot;undefined&quot;,&quot;nc&quot;,&quot;public&quot;,&quot;northampton&quot;,&quot;county&quot;,&quot;school&quot;,&quot;partnerships&quot;,&quot;superintendent&quot;,&quot;monica&quot;,&quot;smith&quot;,&quot;woofter&quot;],&quot;lowSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools undefined grant boosts math instruction in high need schools nc public schools northampton county schools school partnerships grant boosts math instruction in high need schools northampton county schools superintendent monica smith woofter 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 the jack kent cooke foundation in lansdowne virginia has awarded a two year 100 000 grant to north carolina school of science and mathematics to enhance middle school mathematics instruction in northampton county north carolina ncssm will partner with northampton county schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low income high achieving eighth grade students in each year of the grant ultimately this course and related materials will be available online free of charge to schools across the state we especially have to perform better in math northampton county schools superintendent monica smith woofter located in northeastern north carolina along the virginia border the economically distressed northampton county has a history of low student performance on state assessments for the past two years student scores have been lower than the state s overall composite scores students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments with scores 70 percent in every subject but we especially have to perform better in math says northampton county schools superintendent monica smith woofter who attended northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent this partnership with ncssm and the jack kent cooke foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal i believe in our students and i believe in our teachers and i know the great things we are capable of northampton county is one of those places where some exciting things are happening ncssm dean of distance education jamie lathan north carolina school of science and mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school s interactive videoconferencing studios in durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course northampton county schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies north carolina has a lot of potential a lot of intellectual capital that given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel could really make a huge positive impact on the state s future says jamie lathan dean of distance education at ncssm northampton county is one of those places where some exciting things are happening the school leaders from the superintendent s office to teachers in the classrooms are committed to the development of their students we re excited to be partnering with them on this program and we re especially grateful to the jack kent cooke foundation for their support jack kent cooke foundation the jack kent cooke foundation is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need by offering the largest scholarships in the country comprehensive counseling and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school the foundation is dedicated to ensuring high performing low income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally in addition to its scholarship programs the foundation provides grants for innovative high impact initiatives that benefit such students by doing so the cooke foundation seeks to use its resources to end the excellence gap the disparity between the number of low and high income students who reach the top levels of academic performance founded in 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;beth hensley&quot;,&quot;durham public schools&quot;,&quot;distance education&quot;,&quot;school partnerships&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;171&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;617&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;720&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;115&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;6&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;954&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;484&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;167&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;600&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;352&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;410&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:167,&quot;left&quot;:600,&quot;width&quot;:352,&quot;height&quot;:410}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>\\n<p>Each day, Durham Public Schools teacher Elizabeth Hensley comes to the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics campus to connect with a group of advanced middle school students at a handful of schools around Durham, thanks to NCSSM’s interactive videoconferencing studios. The partnership between the Durham schools and NCSSM offers a proof-of-concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology. NCSSM works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools, says Ross White, director of distance education at NCSSM.</p>\\n\\n<p>This is the first year of the Durham middle school program, which aims to “support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade,” explains Elizabeth Cross, director of advanced academics at Durham Public Schools. “It is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth, seventh, and eighth grades — bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace.”</p>\\n\\n<p>To determine how to best serve those “high flyers,” as Cross describes the students, she identified four students who were predicted to do well in Math 1 at the highest level. But those students are enrolled at four different schools. So Durham Public Schools turned to NCSSM’s distance education studios. “The teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience,” says Cross.</p>\\n\\n<p>The program launched during the first week of classes this fall. So far it has been a big success, says Cross. “This is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program. Parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students’ academic needs are met.&nbsp;The&nbsp;students&nbsp;are able to move through the curriculum at a faster pace than they would be able to do in a regular math class. At the same time, they are collaborating with others across the district. This is real twenty-first-century learning at work.”</p>\\n&nbsp;</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;studio students at a handful of schools around durham thanks to ncssm s interactive videoconferencing studios the partnership between the durham schools and ncssm offers a proof of concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology ncssm works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools says ross white director of distance education at ncssm this is the first year of the durham middle school program which aims to support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade explains elizabeth cross director of advanced academics at durham public schools it is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth seventh and eighth grades bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace to determine how to best serve those high flyers as cross describes the students she identified four students who were predicted to do well in math 1 at the highest level but those students are enrolled at four different schools so durham public schools turned to ncssm s distance education studios the teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience says cross the program launched during the first week of classes this fall so far it has been a big success says cross this is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students academic needs are met the students are able to move through the curriculum at a faster work&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\n\\n\\nEach day, Durham Public Schools teacher Elizabeth Hensley comes to the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics campus to connect with a group of advanced middle school students at a handful of schools around Durham, thanks to NCSSM’s interactive videoconferencing studios. The partnership between the Durham schools and NCSSM offers a proof-of-concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology. NCSSM works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools, says Ross White, director of distance education at NCSSM.\\n\\n\\nThis is the first year of the Durham middle school program, which aims to “support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade,” explains Elizabeth Cross, director of advanced academics at Durham Public Schools. “It is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth, seventh, and eighth grades — bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace.”\\n\\n\\nTo determine how to best serve those “high flyers,” as Cross describes the students, she identified four students who were predicted to do well in Math 1 at the highest level. But those students are enrolled at four different schools. So Durham Public Schools turned to NCSSM’s distance education studios. “The teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience,” says Cross.\\n\\n\\nThe program launched during the first week of classes this fall. So far it has been a big success, says Cross. “This is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program. Parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students’ academic needs are met.&nbsp;The&nbsp;students&nbsp;are able to move through the curriculum at a faster pace than they would be able to do in a regular math class. At the same time, they are collaborating with others across the district. This is real twenty-first-century learning at work.”\\n&nbsp;&quot;,&quot;_category&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;684891561223034135&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;category&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-07T17:52:05.012Z&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;On 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news collaborations with schools and districts, in NC and farther afield</h2>\\n\\n<p>Our cost-effective solutions for school districts with tight budgets include a range of collaborations:</p>\\n\\n<ul>\\n\\t<li>enrolling students in&nbsp;enrichment and&nbsp;videoconferencing courses in STEM topics</li>\\n\\t<li>students dual-enrolling&nbsp;in NCSSM Online and their home advance STEM learning.</p>&quot;},{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;editView&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w448219328444591867&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;34176127180472544&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;34176127180472544&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:true,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;34176127180472544&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-11-04T15:01:54.609Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;img-3508-x3&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;ivc boosts math instruction in high-need Woofter&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;aspectRatio&quot;:[18,21],&quot;userOptions&quot;:{&quot;disableTitles&quot;:true,&quot;disableDescriptions&quot;:true,&quot;disableCredits&quot;:true},&quot;itemType&quot;:{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;label&quot;:&quot;Image(s)&quot;,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;icon-image&quot;,&quot;css&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;},&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;position&quot;:&quot;middle&quot;,&quot;size&quot;:&quot;full&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;slideshow&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w298655967647076180&quot;,&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;29248968681278945&quot;],&quot;extras&quot;:{&quot;29248968681278945&quot;:{&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}},&quot;showTitles&quot;:false,&quot;showDescriptions&quot;:false,&quot;showCredits&quot;:false,&quot;_id&quot;:1,&quot;_items&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;29248968681278945&quot;,&quot;length&quot;:null,&quot;group&quot;:&quot;images&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-28T01:45:41.637Z&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;2015-08-25-21-33-38-x3&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3&quot;,&quot;extension&quot;:&quot;jpg&quot;,&quot;md5&quot;:&quot;89a6e63f2e5dffdd8c7f52931f85395f&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:1600,&quot;height&quot;:1067,&quot;searchText&quot;:&quot;2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 2015 08 25 21 33 38 x3 none northampton county schools nc public schools middle school students in northampton county nc listen to a presentation from ncssm instructors working on advanced math curricula jpg images jpeg lisa watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;Middle school students in Northampton County, NC, listen to a presentation from NCSSM instructors working on advanced math curricula&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;northampton county schools&quot;,&quot;nc public schools&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;256&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1272&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1051&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1189&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;342&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;915&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1067&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;330&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;1078&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;1068&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:0,&quot;left&quot;:342,&quot;width&quot;:915,&quot;height&quot;:1067}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>The Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.</div>\\n\\n<div>\\n<div>\\n<h4>“We especially have to perform better in math.” —<em>Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>Located in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.</p>\\n\\n<p>“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”</p>\\n\\n<div>\\n<h4>“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;<em>— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan</em></h4>\\n</div>\\n\\n<p>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.</p>\\n\\n<p>“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”</p>\\n\\n<p><strong>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</strong><br />\\nThe&nbsp;<a href=\\&quot;http://www.jkcf.org\\&quot;>Jack Kent Cooke Foundation</a>&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.</p>\\n</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction in high need schools&quot;,&quot;publishedAt&quot;:&quot;2015-07-22T15:47:00.000Z&quot;,&quot;sortViews&quot;:1250,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[1250],&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;grant boosts math instruction 2000 the foundation has awarded 130 million in scholarships to 1 900 student and over 80 million in grants&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nThe Jack Kent Cooke Foundation in Lansdowne, Virginia, has awarded a two-year, $100,000 grant to North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics to enhance middle-school mathematics instruction in Northampton County, North Carolina. NCSSM will partner with Northampton County Schools to develop and deliver a high school level integrated mathematics course via interactive videoconferencing to approximately 25 low-income, high-achieving eighth-grade students in each year of the grant. Ultimately, this course and related materials will be available online, free of charge, to schools across the state.\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“We especially have to perform better in math.” —Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter\\n\\n\\n\\nLocated in northeastern North Carolina along the Virginia border, the economically distressed Northampton County has a history of low student performance on state assessments. For the past two years, student scores have been lower than the state’s overall composite scores. Students have struggled particularly with mathematics assessments, with scores 70 percent below the state average in the same reporting period. By partnering with NCSSM, &nbsp;the school district hopes to enhance student performance while building teacher capacity.\\n\\n\\n“We’re striving to perform better in every subject, but we especially have to perform better in math,” says Northampton County Schools Superintendent Monica Smith-Woofter, who attended Northampton schools herself and taught in the district before being named superintendent. “This partnership with NCSSM and the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation will give us the momentum we need to achieve that goal. I believe in our students and I believe in our teachers and I know the great things we are capable of.”\\n\\n\\n\\n\\n“Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening.”&nbsp;— NCSSM Dean of Distance Education Jamie Lathan\\n\\n\\n\\nNorth Carolina School of Science and Mathematics faculty will teach the course from the school’s interactive videoconferencing studios in Durham and develop additional digital materials to enhance the course. Northampton County Schools teachers will facilitate the course at their schools while gaining insight into course content and effective teaching methodologies.\\n\\n\\n“North Carolina has a lot of potential, a lot of intellectual capital, that — given the right tools and the right opportunities to develop and excel — could really make a huge positive impact on the state’s future,” says Jamie Lathan, dean of distance education at NCSSM. “Northampton County is one of those places where some exciting things are happening. The school leaders, from the superintendent’s office to teachers in the classrooms, are committed to the development of their students. We’re excited to be partnering with them on this program, and we’re especially grateful to the Jack Kent Cooke Foundation for their support.”\\n\\n\\nJack Kent Cooke Foundation\\n\\nThe&nbsp;Jack Kent Cooke Foundation&nbsp;is dedicated to advancing the education of exceptionally promising students who have financial need. By offering the largest scholarships in the country, comprehensive counseling, and other support services to students from 7th grade to graduate school, the Foundation is dedicated to ensuring high-performing, low-income students have the support necessary to develop their talents and excel educationally. In addition to its scholarship programs, the Foundation provides grants for innovative, high-impact initiatives that benefit such students. By doing so, the Cooke Foundation seeks to use its resources to end the Excellence Gap, the disparity between the number of low- and high-income students who reach the top levels of academic performance. Founded in 2000, the Foundation has awarded $130 million in scholarships to 1,900 student and over $80 million in grants.\\n&quot;,&quot;_bestPage&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;327770981677599635&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;News&quot;,&quot;seoDescription&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;published&quot;:true,&quot;orphan&quot;:false,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;level&quot;:1,&quot;path&quot;:&quot;home/news&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;/news&quot;,&quot;rank&quot;:24,&quot;pagePermissions&quot;:[&quot;edit-240660772394851537&quot;],&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;highSearchText&quot;:&quot;news healthcare&quot;,&quot;withTags&quot;:[],&quot;notTags&quot;:[],&quot;sortViews&quot;:0,&quot;sortViewsByDay&quot;:[0]},&quot;url&quot;:&quot;/news/2015/07/22/grant-boosts-math-instruction-in-high-need-schools&quot;}]},{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;editView&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;news&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w439530555829967934&quot;,&quot;limitByTag&quot;:1,&quot;limit&quot;:1,&quot;by&quot;:&quot;id&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[],&quot;ids&quot;:[&quot;264391422835629886&quot;],&quot;_snippets&quot;:[{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;264391422835629886&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;post&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-25T21:27:33.586Z&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;Studio helps serve advanced middle hensley in watts&quot;,&quot;landscape&quot;:true,&quot;ownerId&quot;:&quot;26034325849012107&quot;,&quot;description&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;tags&quot;:[&quot;beth hensley&quot;,&quot;durham public schools&quot;,&quot;distance education&quot;,&quot;school partnerships&quot;],&quot;private&quot;:false,&quot;crops&quot;:[{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;171&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;617&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;720&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;115&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;6&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;954&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;484&quot;},{&quot;top&quot;:&quot;167&quot;,&quot;left&quot;:&quot;600&quot;,&quot;width&quot;:&quot;352&quot;,&quot;height&quot;:&quot;410&quot;}],&quot;hyperlink&quot;:null,&quot;hyperlinkTitle&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;hyperlinkTarget&quot;:false,&quot;crop&quot;:{&quot;top&quot;:167,&quot;left&quot;:600,&quot;width&quot;:352,&quot;height&quot;:410}}]}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers:thumbnail&quot;},&quot;body&quot;:{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;type&quot;:&quot;richText&quot;,&quot;content&quot;:&quot;<div>\\n<p>Each day, Durham Public Schools teacher Elizabeth Hensley comes to the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics campus to connect with a group of advanced middle school students at a handful of schools around Durham, thanks to NCSSM’s interactive videoconferencing studios. The partnership between the Durham schools and NCSSM offers a proof-of-concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology. NCSSM works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools, says Ross White, director of distance education at NCSSM.</p>\\n\\n<p>This is the first year of the Durham middle school program, which aims to “support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade,” explains Elizabeth Cross, director of advanced academics at Durham Public Schools. “It is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth, seventh, and eighth grades — bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace.”</p>\\n\\n<p>To determine how to best serve those “high flyers,” as Cross describes the students, she identified four students who were predicted to do well in Math 1 at the highest level. But those students are enrolled at four different schools. So Durham Public Schools turned to NCSSM’s distance education studios. “The teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience,” says Cross.</p>\\n\\n<p>The program launched during the first week of classes this fall. So far it has been a big success, says Cross. “This is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program. Parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students’ academic needs are met.&nbsp;The&nbsp;students&nbsp;are able to move through the curriculum at a faster pace than they would be able to do in a regular math class. At the same time, they are collaborating with others across the district. This is real twenty-first-century learning at work.”</p>\\n&nbsp;</div>&quot;}],&quot;type&quot;:&quot;area&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers:body&quot;},&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;studio-helps-serve-advanced-middle-schoolers&quot;,&quot;sortTitle&quot;:&quot;studio helps serve advanced middle work&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\n\\n\\nEach day, Durham Public Schools teacher Elizabeth Hensley comes to the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics campus to connect with a group of advanced middle school students at a handful of schools around Durham, thanks to NCSSM’s interactive videoconferencing studios. The partnership between the Durham schools and NCSSM offers a proof-of-concept for serving gifted kids and widening the pipeline of students ready for advanced math offerings through technology. NCSSM works with school districts across the state to provide similar services at no charge to schools, says Ross White, director of distance education at NCSSM.\\n\\n\\nThis is the first year of the Durham middle school program, which aims to “support our highest math ability students transitioning from fifth to sixth grade,” explains Elizabeth Cross, director of advanced academics at Durham Public Schools. “It is a class that compacts math topics which span sixth, seventh, and eighth grades — bringing together students from across the district who are so advanced in math that they need the compacting to continue their advancement at a proper pace.”\\n\\n\\nTo determine how to best serve those “high flyers,” as Cross describes the students, she identified four students who were predicted to do well in Math 1 at the highest level. But those students are enrolled at four different schools. So Durham Public Schools turned to NCSSM’s distance education studios. “The teacher is able to teach the students all at once and provide them with an amazing interactive experience,” says Cross.\\n\\n\\nThe program launched during the first week of classes this fall. So far it has been a big success, says Cross. “This is empowering to the students to be able to do this on their own and connect with other students in the program. Parents are appreciative that we have identified a need and are going to great lengths to ensure that these students’ academic needs are met.&nbsp;The&nbsp;students&nbsp;are able to move through the curriculum at a faster pace than they would be able to do in a regular math class. At the same time, they are collaborating with others across the district. This is real twenty-first-century learning at work.”\\n&nbsp;&quot;,&quot;_category&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;684891561223034135&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;category&quot;,&quot;createdAt&quot;:&quot;2015-10-07T17:52:05.012Z&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;On investing in ncssm you support our many programs enhance the experience of students both on campus and across the state to help us expand our offerings so that we continue to provide once in a ncssm from gifts to the greater challenge fund to participating in loyalty programs your contributions add up to make a big difference for our students volunteer giving doesn t always involve dollar signs whether you have a couple of hours to lend a hand at an admissions event or want to mentor a student in your workplace your time and talents can be enormous gifts your gift in action the graduation&quot;,&quot;searchSummary&quot;:&quot;\\nMake a gift. Get involved. There are many ways to give to NCSSM. Find the one that’s right for you.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\n\\n\\nYour gift&nbsp;adds up to make a big difference.\\n\\n\\nGifts of any size can have a big impact at NCSSM. By investing in NCSSM, you support&nbsp;our many programs, enhance the experience of students both on&nbsp;campus and across the state,&nbsp;to help us expand our offerings so that we continue to provide once-in-a-lifetime opportunities to our students.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nMake your donation&nbsp;today, and see how your gift makes an impact at NCSSM. &nbsp;\\n \\nYour gift&nbsp;adds up to make a big difference.\\n\\n\\nGifts of any size can have a big impact at NCSSM. By investing in NCSSM, you support&nbsp;our many programs, enhance the experience of students both on&nbsp;campus and across the state,&nbsp;to help us expand our offerings so that we continue to provide once-in-a-lifetime opportunities to our students.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nMake your donation to the NCSSM Foundation today, and see how your gift makes an impact at NCSSM.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp;\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nInvest in NCSSM\\n\\n\\nThe NCSSM Foundation helps support a wide range of academic, athletic, and other student programs and activities.&nbsp;Your gift enriches the NCSSM experience and makes a real difference in the lives our students.&nbsp; \\nWays to give\\n\\n\\nThere are many ways to support NCSSM. From gifts to the Greater Challenge Fund to participating in Loyalty Programs, your contributions add up to make a big difference for our students. \\n&nbsp;Volunteer\\n\\n\\nGiving doesn't always involve dollar signs. Whether you have a couple of hours to lend a hand at an admissions event or&nbsp;want&nbsp;to mentor a student in your workplace, your time and talents can be enormous gifts. \\nYour Gift in Action\\n\\n\\nThe collective generosity of donors like you helps sustain successful programs and fund new learning opportunities for students at NCSSM.  \\nYour gift&nbsp;adds up to make a big difference.\\n\\n\\nGifts of any size can have a big impact at NCSSM. By investing in NCSSM, you support&nbsp;our many programs, enhance the experience of students both on&nbsp;campus and across the state,&nbsp;to help us expand our offerings so that we continue to provide once-in-a-lifetime opportunities to our students.&nbsp;\\n\\n\\nMake your donation to the NCSSM Foundation today, and see how your gift makes an impact at NCSSM. \\nInvest in NCSSM\\n\\n\\nThe NCSSM Foundation helps support a wide range of academic, athletic, and other student programs and activities.&nbsp;Your gift enriches the NCSSM experience and makes a real difference in the lives our students.&nbsp;&nbsp; \\nWays to give\\n\\n\\nThere are many ways to support NCSSM. From gifts to the Greater Challenge Fund to participating in Loyalty Programs, your contributions add up to make a big difference for our students.\\n\\n\\n&nbsp; \\nGet Involved\\n\\n\\nGiving doesn't always involve dollar signs. Whether you have a couple of hours to lend a hand at an admissions event or&nbsp;want&nbsp;to mentor a student in your workplace, your time and talents can be enormous gifts. \\nYour Gift in Action\\n\\n\\nThe collective generosity of donors like you helps sustain successful programs and fund new learning opportunities for students at NCSSM.&nbsp; \\nDonate\\n\\n\\nGifts of any size can have a big impact at NCSSM. class=\"apos-rich-text\" data-rich-text=\"\"><h3><strong>North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics&nbsp;is the nation's first public residential high school focused on science, technology, engineering, and math.<br>\nWe challenge and inspire talented students from across North Carolina through a residential campus, online program, summer STEM enrichment programs, and distance offerings for schools and educators.</strong></h3>\n\n</div></div></div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n</div>\n  \n\n  \n\n\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n</div>\n  \n\n  \n    \n  \n    \n class=\"apos-rich-text\" data-rich-text=\"\"><h3>Higher Ed Works: NCSSM 'best high-school education in country'</h3>\n\n<p>Higher Education Works&nbsp;highlighted NCSSM in a feature story and video, titled \"NCSSM: 'Best high-school education win the country.'\" The feature appears as part of their series \"What makes a great university.\" NCSSM is the only high school to be featured in the series.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"http://www.higheredworksfoundation.org/2017/02/ncssm-best-high-school/\">Read the full story from Higher Education Works&nbsp;</a></p>\n\n</div></div></div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n</div></div><div class=\"apos-item apos-widget apos-facts     \" data=\"{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;stat&quot;:&quot;96%&quot;,&quot;body&quot;:&quot;Record percentage of North Carolina counties with students applying for the Class of 2018, residential and online. Our resulting class represents 82 of the state's 100 counties.&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;color&quot;:&quot;blue&quot;,&quot;linkType&quot;:&quot;internal&quot;,&quot;pageId&quot;:&quot;860522062892901766&quot;,&quot;link&quot;:null,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;facts&quot;}\" data-id=\"\" data-type=\"facts\">\n\n\n\n\t\n\n\n\n<a href=\"/welcome-class-of-2018\" class=\"fact\">\n\t<div class=\"fact-content blue\">\n\t\t<div class=\"fact-stat\">\n\t\t\t96%\n\t\t</div>\n\t\t<div class=\"fact-body\">\n\t\t\t<div class=\"fact-text\">\n\t\t\t\t<p>Record percentage of North Carolina counties with students applying for the Class of 2018, residential and online. Our resulting class represents 82 of the state's 100 counties.</p>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n</a></div><div class=\"apos-item apos-widget apos-feature     \" class=\"apos-rich-text\" data-rich-text=\"\"><h3>Seven instructors win UNC BOG Teaching Awards</h3>\n\n<p>The seven recipients of this year’s NCSSM Teaching Awards are (l-r): Joe Lobuglio, Bob Gotwals, Katie Moulder, Jackie Bondell, Gina Burger, and Martha Regalis, with Chancellor Todd Roberts. Not pictured: Julie Graves. Chemistry Instructor Bob Gotwals is this year's winner of the&nbsp;Excellence in Teaching award.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.ncssm.edu/news/2017/02/10/gotwals-wins-unc-teaching-excellence-award\">Read more</a> &nbsp;</p>\n\n</div></div></div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n</div></div><div class=\"apos-item apos-widget apos-embed     \" data=\"{&quot;widget&quot;:true,&quot;editView&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;embed&quot;,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;w942025128471044427&quot;,&quot;video&quot;:&quot;https://www.instagram.com/p/BQneOcSDvEQ/?taken-by=ncssmunis&quot;,&quot;thumbnail&quot;:&quot;https://scontent.cdninstagram.com/t51.2885-15/s640x640/sh0.08/e35/16230366_410244762656508_532886062817607680_n.jpg&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;12 students left for the Big 🍎 Sunday to experience the history and culture of the city. class=\"apos-rich-text\" data-rich-text=\"\"><h3>Lean In, Women in Science returns in April&nbsp;</h3>\n\n<p>Lean In, Women in Science will return for the third year in April. The event, part of the NC Science Festival,&nbsp;features accomplished women scientists talking about their careers, challenges, and successes, then talking with students in small groups over dinner.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.ncssm.edu/leaninncssm\">Learn more and register for the dinner here&nbsp;</a></p>\n\n</div></div></div>\n class=\"apos-rich-text\" data-rich-text=\"\"><h3>Dory Li ‘17 presents research at CED Conference</h3>\n\n<p>Senior Dory Li recently presented her research at the CED Life Science Conference in Raleigh,&nbsp;“one of the leading life science gatherings in the nation.” Li&nbsp;was one of five featured speakers,&nbsp;and the only high school student to present, at the conference, which&nbsp;draws a powerful mix of scientists, executives, entrepreneurs, educators and investors to the Triangle each year to celebrate the flourishing life science industry in North Carolina.</p>\n\n<p><a href=\"https://www.ncssm.edu/news/2017/03/10/dory-li-17-presents-research-at-ced-conference\">Read more</a></p>\n\n</div></div></div>\n give back on MLK Day&nbsp;</h3>\\n\\n<p>NCSSM celebrates&nbsp;the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. each year with a day of service activities, sessions centered on diversity and inclusion, and community-building conversations. Students and staff gave back at locations around the Triangle, including the students above, who participated in a service project at E.K. Powe elementary school. <a href=\\&quot;https://www.facebook.com/NCSSM/photos/a.1220894884614981.1073741916.190860967618383/1221354471235689/?type=3&amp;amp;theater\\&quot;>See more photos from the class=\"apos-rich-text\" data-rich-text=\"\"><h3>Students give back on MLK Day&nbsp;</h3>\n\n<p>NCSSM celebrates&nbsp;the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. each year with a day of service activities, sessions centered on diversity and inclusion, and community-building conversations. Students and staff gave back at locations around the Triangle, including the students above, who participated in a service project at E.K. Powe elementary school. <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/NCSSM/photos/a.1220894884614981.1073741916.190860967618383/1221354471235689/?type=3&amp;theater\">See more photos from the
